Measures the proportion of male teachers in primary education who have received the minimum organized pedagogical training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country. It is expressed as a percentage of the total number of male primary school teachers. This indicator reflects a country's commitment to quality education, although national standards for teacher training vary.

Measures the proportion of all teachers in primary education who have received the minimum organized pedagogical training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country. It is expressed as a percentage of the total number of primary school teachers. This indicator reflects a country's commitment to quality education, although national standards for teacher training vary.

Represents the total number of teachers employed in an official capacity at the primary education level. The count includes both full-time and part-time teachers but excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties, such as principals who do not teach, or those who work on an occasional or voluntary basis. This indicator provides a measure of the human resource capacity of a country's primary education system.

Measures the share of primary education teaching positions that are held by women, expressed as a percentage of the total number of primary school teachers (both male and female). This indicator includes both full-time and part-time teachers and is used to assess gender representation within the teaching profession at the primary level.

Measures the enrollment of children within the official primary school age group, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age range. This 'adjusted' rate includes children of primary school age who are enrolled in either primary or secondary education. It provides a more complete picture of school participation for this age group than the standard net enrollment rate by capturing students who may have advanced to secondary school early.

Measures the enrollment of female children within the official primary school age group, expressed as a percentage of the total female population in that age range. This 'adjusted' rate includes female children of primary school age who are enrolled in either primary or secondary education. It provides a more complete picture of school participation for this age group than the standard net enrollment rate by capturing students who may have advanced to secondary school early.

Measures the enrollment of male children within the official primary school age group, expressed as a percentage of the total male population in that age range. This 'adjusted' rate includes male children of primary school age who are enrolled in either primary or secondary education. It provides a more complete picture of school participation for this age group than the standard net enrollment rate by capturing students who may have advanced to secondary school early.

Represents the total number of children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school. This figure is calculated by subtracting the number of enrolled primary-age children from the total population of that age group. It includes children who have never attended school, those who may enroll later, and those who have dropped out.

Represents the total number of female children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school. This figure is calculated by subtracting the number of enrolled primary-age female children from the total female population of that age group. It includes girls who have never attended school, those who may enroll later, and those who have dropped out.

Measures the share of female children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the female primary-school-age population. For the purpose of this indicator, children in the official primary age group who are still in pre-primary education are considered to be out of school. It reflects the proportion of girls who have not entered the formal primary or secondary education system at the expected age.

Represents the total number of male children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school. This figure is calculated by subtracting the number of enrolled primary-age male children from the total male population of that age group. It includes boys who have never attended school, those who may enroll later, and those who have dropped out.

Measures the share of male children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the male primary-school-age population. For the purpose of this indicator, children in the official primary age group who are still in pre-primary education are considered to be out of school. It reflects the proportion of boys who have not entered the formal primary or secondary education system at the expected age.

Measures the share of all children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the total primary-school-age population. For the purpose of this indicator, children in the official primary age group who are still in pre-primary education are considered to be out of school. It reflects the proportion of children who have not entered the formal primary or secondary education system at the expected age.

Represents the theoretical age, in years, at which a student would begin lower secondary education. This age is based on the assumption that the student started primary school at the official entrance age, progressed through the system without repeating or skipping any grades, and studied full-time. It reflects the official structure of a country's education system rather than the actual age of students entering this level.

Measures the percentage of females in the relevant age group who complete lower secondary education. It is calculated as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of this level, which divides the number of new female entrants into the final grade of lower secondary school (regardless of age) by the female population at the official entrance age for that grade. This indicator serves as a proxy for completion and can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-age or early-entrant students.

Measures the percentage of males in the relevant age group who complete lower secondary education. It is calculated as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of this level, which divides the number of new male entrants into the final grade of lower secondary school (regardless of age) by the male population at the official entrance age for that grade. This indicator serves as a proxy for completion and can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-age or early-entrant students.

Measures the lower secondary education completion rate, expressed as a percentage of the relevant age group. It is calculated as a gross intake ratio, which is the number of new entrants in the last grade of lower secondary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the official entrance age for that grade. This indicator serves as a proxy for completion, assuming all students who enter the final grade will graduate. Because it includes over-age and under-age students, the rate can exceed 100% and is considered an upper-bound estimate of actual completion.

Measures the percentage of the female population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least lower secondary education. As a cumulative indicator, it includes all women who have reached this level or any higher level of education. Calculated using data from national censuses and household surveys standardized under the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), this metric reflects the stock of human capital in the adult female population and provides insights into historical access to education and gender equity.

Measures the percentage of the male population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least lower secondary education. As a cumulative indicator, it includes all men who have reached this level or any higher level of education. Calculated using data from national censuses and household surveys standardized under the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), this metric reflects the stock of human capital in the adult male population and provides insights into historical access to education.

Measures the percentage of the total population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least lower secondary education. This is a cumulative indicator, including all adults who have reached this educational level or higher. The data is calculated from national censuses and household surveys, standardized using the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), to reflect the overall stock of human capital in a country's adult population and the historical effectiveness of its education system.

Measures the percentage of the female population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least post-secondary non-tertiary education. As a cumulative indicator, it includes all women who have reached this level or any higher level of education (e.g., tertiary). Data is sourced from national censuses and household surveys, standardized using the ISCED framework. This metric serves as a proxy for the advanced skills and human capital within the adult female population.

Measures the percentage of the male population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least post-secondary non-tertiary education. As a cumulative indicator, it includes all men who have reached this level or any higher level of education (e.g., tertiary). Data is sourced from national censuses and household surveys, standardized using the ISCED framework. This metric serves as a proxy for the advanced skills and human capital within the adult male population.

Measures the percentage of the total population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least post-secondary non-tertiary education. This is a cumulative indicator, including all adults who have reached this educational level or higher. The data is calculated from national censuses and household surveys, standardized using the ISCED framework, to serve as a proxy for the advanced skills and human capital within a country's adult population.

Measures the percentage of the female population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least upper secondary education. This cumulative indicator counts all women who have achieved this level or any higher educational level (e.g., post-secondary or tertiary). The calculation is based on data from national censuses and household surveys, standardized internationally using the ISCED framework. It indicates the proportion of the adult female population equipped with foundational skills for higher education or skilled employment.

Measures the percentage of the male population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least upper secondary education. This cumulative indicator counts all men who have achieved this level or any higher educational level (e.g., post-secondary or tertiary). The calculation is based on data from national censuses and household surveys, standardized internationally using the ISCED framework. It indicates the proportion of the adult male population equipped with foundational skills for higher education or skilled employment.

Measures the percentage of the total population aged 25 and over who have attained or successfully completed at least upper secondary education. This cumulative indicator counts all adults who have achieved this level or any higher educational level. The calculation is based on data from national censuses and household surveys, standardized internationally using the ISCED framework. It indicates the proportion of the adult population equipped with the foundational skills for higher education or skilled employment.

Measures the official duration of secondary education in a country, expressed in the number of grades or years. This figure is based on national laws and regulations as reported to UNESCO and standardized using the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). It represents the total intended length of the secondary education cycle, typically including both lower and upper secondary levels. This indicator is a key structural parameter of a nation's education system but does not reflect actual student attendance or completion rates.

Represents the total number of students enrolled in secondary education, measured as a head count. This figure includes students of all ages who are officially registered in secondary-level programs, encompassing both lower and upper secondary stages. The data covers enrollment in all types of institutions, including public and private schools, as well as general and vocational tracks. It provides a measure of the absolute size of the secondary education system.

Measures the share of female students in the total enrollment for secondary education, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the total number of female pupils at the secondary level by the total number of pupils (male and female) at the same level. This indicator provides a snapshot of the gender composition within secondary schools, including both public and private institutions. It does not adjust for the overall gender ratio in the country's population, for which the Gender Parity Index is a more precise measure of equity.

Represents the total number of students enrolled in general secondary education programs, measured as a head count. This figure specifically counts pupils in academic tracks that are not primarily designed to lead to a specific occupation or trade. It includes students in teacher training programs at the secondary level but excludes those enrolled in vocational or technical education. This indicator helps to differentiate the size of the general education stream from the vocational stream within the secondary system.

Measures the percentage of students in general secondary education programs who are female. It is calculated by dividing the number of female pupils enrolled in general tracks (including teacher training) by the total enrollment in those same programs. The indicator provides insight into the gender composition specifically within the non-vocational, academic stream of secondary education and helps in analyzing gender-based preferences or access to different types of secondary schooling.

Measures the average number of pupils per teacher at the lower secondary level of education. It is calculated by dividing the total number of students enrolled in lower secondary schools by the total number of teachers at that level. This ratio is often used as a proxy for educational resources and potential teacher workload, but as a national average, it does not reflect variations in class size across schools or regions and is considered a weak proxy for education quality.

Measures the average number of pupils per teacher across all secondary education levels, including both lower and upper secondary. It is calculated by dividing the total number of students enrolled in secondary schools by the total number of teachers working at that level. The ratio provides a general indication of human resource allocation in secondary education but, as a national average, does not account for differences in class size or teacher distribution and is a limited indicator of overall educational quality.

Measures the average number of pupils per teacher at the upper secondary level of education. It is calculated by dividing the total number of students enrolled in upper secondary schools by the total number of teachers at that level. This ratio is often used as a proxy for educational resources and potential teacher workload for the final stage of secondary education. However, as a national average, it does not reflect variations in class size across schools or programs.

Represents the total number of students enrolled in technical and vocational education programs at the secondary level, measured as a head count. This figure counts pupils in educational tracks specifically designed to impart job-related skills and prepare them for a particular trade or occupation. It excludes students enrolled in general academic programs and shows the scale of vocational training within a country's secondary education system.

Measures the percentage of students in technical and vocational secondary education programs who are female. It is calculated by dividing the number of female pupils enrolled in vocational tracks by the total enrollment in those same programs. This indicator provides insight into female participation in job-specific training at the secondary level and can be used to analyze gender distribution across different educational streams and potential occupational pathways.

Measures the gross enrollment ratio (GER) for secondary education, which indicates the total enrollment in secondary school as a percentage of the population in the official secondary school age group. It is calculated by dividing the total number of students enrolled, regardless of their age, by the population of the age group that officially corresponds to secondary education. This indicator reflects the capacity of an education system, and values can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-age or under-age students.

Measures the gross enrollment ratio (GER) for females in secondary education, showing total female enrollment as a percentage of the female population in the official secondary school age group. It is calculated by dividing the total number of female students enrolled, regardless of age, by the female population of the officially corresponding age group. This ratio indicates the education system's capacity to enroll female students, and like the overall GER, can exceed 100% due to over-age or under-age enrollment.

Measures the gross enrollment ratio (GER) for males in secondary education, showing total male enrollment as a percentage of the male population in the official secondary school age group. It is calculated by dividing the total number of male students enrolled, regardless of age, by the male population of the officially corresponding age group. This ratio indicates the education system's capacity to enroll male students, and like the overall GER, can exceed 100% due to over-age or under-age enrollment.

Measures the net enrollment rate (NER) for secondary education, which is the percentage of the official secondary school-aged population that is actually enrolled in secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the number of students enrolled in secondary education who are within the official age group for that level by the total population of that same age group. Unlike the gross enrollment ratio, the NER specifically measures on-time enrollment, cannot exceed 100%, and provides a more precise measure of participation for the target age cohort.

Measures the net enrollment rate (NER) for females in secondary education, representing the percentage of the official female secondary school-aged population enrolled in secondary school. The calculation divides the number of female students within the official secondary school age range who are enrolled at that level by the total female population of that same age group. This indicator specifically tracks on-time enrollment for girls, cannot exceed 100%, and is a key metric for assessing educational access and efficiency for females.

Measures the net enrollment rate (NER) for males in secondary education, representing the percentage of the official male secondary school-aged population enrolled in secondary school. The calculation divides the number of male students within the official secondary school age range who are enrolled at that level by the total male population of that same age group. This indicator specifically tracks on-time enrollment for boys, cannot exceed 100%, and is a key metric for assessing educational access and efficiency for males.

Measures the share of total secondary school enrollment that is in private institutions, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of students enrolled in private secondary schools by the total secondary enrollment (in both public and private schools). Private institutions are defined as those controlled and managed by a non-governmental body, such as a religious organization, NGO, or business, regardless of whether they are for-profit. This indicator reflects the scale of the private sector's involvement in providing secondary education.

Measures the effective transition rate for female students from primary to secondary education, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of new female entrants to the first grade of secondary school in a given year by the number of female students who were enrolled in the final grade of primary school in the previous year. This indicator shows the percentage of a female student cohort that moves from one level of education to the next, reflecting the education system's capacity to retain students through this critical transition.

Measures the effective transition rate for male students from primary to secondary education, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of new male entrants to the first grade of secondary school in a given year by the number of male students who were enrolled in the final grade of primary school in the previous year. This indicator shows the percentage of a male student cohort that moves from one level of education to the next, reflecting the education system's capacity to retain students through this critical transition.

Measures the effective transition rate for all students from primary to secondary education, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of new entrants to the first grade of secondary school in a given year by the number of students enrolled in the final grade of primary school in the previous year. This indicator shows the percentage of a student cohort that moves from one level of education to the next, reflecting the education system's overall capacity to retain students through this critical transition.

Measures the proportion of female teachers in secondary education who have received the minimum required pedagogical training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female secondary school teachers. This includes teachers who have completed either pre-service or in-service training as defined by national standards. The indicator serves as a proxy for the quality of the teaching workforce but does not account for teachers' experience, status, or classroom effectiveness. The definition of 'minimum training' can vary between countries.

Measures the share of female teachers in lower secondary education who have met the minimum national requirements for teacher training. It is expressed as a percentage of all female teachers at this level. The training can be either pre-service or in-service. This metric reflects a country's commitment to quality education standards for its early adolescent students but does not capture other quality factors like teacher experience or professional development. National standards for minimum training requirements may differ.

Measures the proportion of male teachers in lower secondary education who have received the minimum required pedagogical training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at this level. This includes both pre-service and in-service training according to national standards. The indicator provides insight into the qualifications of the male teaching force at this specific educational stage, although the definition of 'minimum training' varies by country and does not reflect teaching experience or effectiveness.

Represents the percentage of all teachers in lower secondary education, regardless of gender, who have received the minimum required teacher training (pre-service or in-service). It is calculated by dividing the number of trained teachers by the total number of teachers at this level. This indicator reflects the overall qualification level of the teaching workforce for early adolescents, though national standards for what constitutes 'trained' can vary, and it does not measure teaching quality or experience.

Measures the share of male teachers in secondary education (both lower and upper levels) who have received the minimum nationally-defined pedagogical training. This is expressed as a percentage of all male secondary school teachers. Training can be pre-service or in-service. While this indicator is a key measure of the formal qualifications of the male teaching staff, it does not account for factors like teaching experience, effectiveness, or the specific standards for 'minimum training,' which can differ across countries.

Measures the proportion of female teachers in upper secondary education who have completed the minimum required pedagogical training, expressed as a percentage of all female teachers at this level. The training can be pre-service or in-service, based on the standards set by the country. This metric indicates the level of formal qualification within the female teaching workforce for older adolescents, but it does not capture teaching quality or experience, and the definition of 'minimum training' is subject to national variation.

Represents the percentage of male teachers in upper secondary education who have received the minimum required teacher training (pre-service or in-service). The value is calculated relative to the total number of male teachers at the upper secondary level. It serves as an indicator of the formal qualification of the male teaching force, though it's important to note that national standards for 'minimum training' vary and the metric does not measure teaching effectiveness or experience.

Measures the percentage of all teachers in upper secondary education who have met the minimum national requirements for pedagogical training. This includes both pre-service and in-service training. The indicator reflects the overall preparedness of the teaching force at this advanced secondary level. However, it does not consider other quality determinants like teacher experience, and the standards for 'minimum training' can differ significantly from one country to another.

Represents the percentage of all teachers in secondary education (covering both lower and upper levels) who have received the minimum organized teacher training required for teaching in a given country. This includes both pre-service and in-service training. The indicator provides a broad measure of the formal qualifications of a country's secondary teaching workforce, but it does not account for teaching quality, experience, or variations in national training standards.

Represents the total number of teachers at the secondary education level. This is a headcount that includes both full-time and part-time personnel officially employed to guide and direct student learning. The definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties, such as principals who do not teach, as well as those who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity.

Measures the total number of female teachers employed at the secondary education level. This figure is a headcount that includes both full-time and part-time female teachers. It excludes educational personnel without active teaching responsibilities (e.g., non-teaching principals) and individuals who teach on an occasional or voluntary basis. The indicator reflects the absolute size of the female teaching force in secondary education.

Measures the share of female teachers within the total teaching workforce at the secondary education level, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the total number of female secondary teachers (both full-time and part-time) by the total number of secondary teachers. This indicator is a key measure of gender representation and parity in the teaching profession but does not provide information on teaching quality or effectiveness.

Measures the percentage of female adolescents of official lower secondary school age who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary school. It is calculated as the number of out-of-school female adolescents divided by the total female population of that specific age group. This group includes individuals who have never attended school, those who may enroll late, and those who have dropped out, providing a key metric for identifying educational exclusion.

Measures the percentage of male adolescents of official lower secondary school age who are not enrolled in any level of school (primary or secondary). The value is calculated by dividing the number of out-of-school male adolescents by the total male population of the corresponding age group. This indicator helps identify educational marginalization among males, covering those who have never enrolled, may enroll late, or have left school prematurely.

Represents the proportion of adolescents of official lower secondary school age who are not enrolled in school, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age group. This indicator provides a comprehensive measure of educational exclusion for this demographic, encompassing adolescents who never entered school, those who have dropped out, and those who may start their education late. It is a critical metric for monitoring progress towards universal education.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the female population aged 25 and over that has successfully attained or completed at least a Bachelor's degree or an equivalent level of education. This indicator reflects the stock of high-level human capital among adult women in a country, based on the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). It measures the level of schooling achieved rather than the quality of the education received.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the male population aged 25 and older who have attained or completed at least a Bachelor's degree or an equivalent qualification. This metric serves as an indicator of the accumulated stock of advanced knowledge and skills within the adult male population, according to the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). It reflects the quantity of educational attainment, not its quality.

Represents the cumulative percentage of the total population aged 25 and over that has attained or completed at least a Bachelor's degree or an equivalent level of education. This indicator provides a broad measure of a country's stock of highly educated human capital, standardized using the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). It quantifies educational attainment levels but does not assess the quality of the learning.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the female population aged 25 and over who have attained or completed a Doctoral degree or an equivalent level of education. This indicator signifies the highest level of educational attainment and research capacity among adult women in a society, as classified by the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). It reflects the quantity of individuals reaching this advanced academic level, not the quality of their research or education.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the male population aged 25 and older who have successfully attained or completed a Doctoral degree or an equivalent qualification. As the pinnacle of formal education according to the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), this indicator reflects the stock of top-tier human capital and research expertise among adult men. It focuses on the level of attainment rather than the quality of education.

Represents the cumulative percentage of the total population aged 25 and over that has attained or completed a Doctoral degree or its equivalent. This indicator measures the proportion of the adult population with the highest level of formal education, reflecting a nation's capacity for advanced research and innovation. Data is classified according to the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), and it does not measure educational quality.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the female population aged 25 and older that has attained or completed at least a Master's degree or an equivalent level of education. This metric reflects the stock of advanced human capital among adult women, classified according to the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED). The indicator focuses on the level of educational attainment rather than the quality of the education or skills acquired.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the male population aged 25 and over who have attained or completed at least a Master's degree or an equivalent qualification. Based on the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), this indicator provides insight into the prevalence of advanced skills and knowledge within the adult male population. It is a measure of the quantity of education completed, not its qualitative aspects.

Represents the cumulative percentage of the total population aged 25 and over that has attained or completed at least a Master's degree or its equivalent. This indicator serves as a proxy for the stock of high-level skills and expertise in a country's adult population. Educational levels are categorized using the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED) to ensure comparability, but the indicator does not assess the quality of the education.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the female population aged 25 and older who have attained or completed at least a short-cycle tertiary education. Short-cycle tertiary programs are often designed to provide professional or vocational skills. This indicator reflects the share of adult women with post-secondary, but pre-bachelor's level, qualifications according to the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), focusing on attainment level, not quality.

Measures the cumulative percentage of the male population aged 25 and over that has attained or completed at least a short-cycle tertiary education. This level of education is typically focused on providing practical, technical, or occupational skills. The indicator, based on the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), gauges the prevalence of post-secondary vocational training among adult men but does not assess educational quality.

Represents the cumulative percentage of the total population aged 25 and over that has attained or completed at least a short-cycle tertiary education. This indicator measures the stock of individuals with post-secondary vocational or technical qualifications that are below the level of a full bachelor's degree. It is based on the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED) and reflects the quantity, not the quality, of this level of educational attainment.

Measures the average number of students enrolled in tertiary education per teacher at that level. This ratio is calculated by dividing the total number of tertiary students by the total number of tertiary teachers. While often used as a proxy for educational quality and teacher workload, its comparability across countries can be affected by differences in how teachers (e.g., full-time vs. part-time) are counted and variations in class sizes and teaching hours.

Represents the gross enrollment ratio in tertiary education, which is the total enrollment, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population in the official age group for tertiary education (typically the five-year age group following upper secondary). A ratio above 100% indicates the inclusion of students outside the official age range (over-age or under-age students). This indicator reflects the general capacity of a country's higher education system but not necessarily the rate of participation by the official age cohort.

Measures the gross enrollment ratio for females in tertiary education. It is calculated by dividing the total number of female students enrolled in tertiary education, regardless of their age, by the female population of the official age group for this level. Expressed as a percentage, a value exceeding 100% is possible and signifies the enrollment of women outside the typical age cohort. The indicator reflects the capacity of the higher education system to accommodate female students.

Measures the gross enrollment ratio for males in tertiary education, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the total number of male students enrolled in tertiary education, regardless of their age, by the male population of the age group that officially corresponds to this level of schooling. Tertiary education is defined as post-secondary schooling that typically requires successful completion of the secondary level. Because this gross ratio includes students of all ages, it can exceed 100%, often indicating the presence of over-aged students due to late entry or repetition.

Measures the percentage of academic staff in tertiary education who are female. This indicator is calculated by dividing the total number of female academic staff at the tertiary level by the total academic staff at the same level, then multiplying by 100. It serves as a key metric for assessing gender representation and equality within the teaching profession at the higher education level, though it does not measure teaching effectiveness or quality.

Represents the share of current expenditure as a percentage of total direct expenditure in public primary educational institutions. Current expenditure refers to spending that is consumed within the current year, such as staff compensation, teaching materials, administrative costs, and ancillary services. This indicator excludes capital expenditure (e.g., for construction) and financial aid or other transfers to students, providing insight into the allocation of funds for the day-to-day operational costs of primary education.

Represents the share of current expenditure as a percentage of total direct expenditure in public secondary educational institutions. Current expenditure is defined as spending that is consumed within the current year and includes costs like staff compensation, teaching materials, administration, and ancillary services. The measure excludes capital expenditure (long-term investments like new buildings) and financial aid or transfers to students, thus focusing on the operational spending within secondary education.

Represents the share of current expenditure as a percentage of total direct expenditure in public tertiary educational institutions. Current expenditure refers to spending consumed within the current year on goods and services such as staff compensation, teaching materials, administration, and ancillary services. This indicator excludes capital expenditure (e.g., construction and major equipment) and financial aid or other transfers to students, highlighting the proportion of the budget dedicated to the operational costs of tertiary education.

Measures the share of current expenditure as a percentage of total direct expenditure in public educational institutions across all levels combined. Current expenditure consists of spending on goods and services consumed within the current year, such as staff salaries, teaching materials, and administrative costs. This metric excludes capital expenditure (long-term investments) and transfers like student aid, thereby indicating the proportion of the education budget allocated to ongoing operational expenses.

Measures the average government expenditure per primary school student, expressed as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita. It is calculated by dividing the total government spending on primary education (including current, capital, and transfers) by the total number of primary school students, and then dividing that result by the GDP per capita. This indicator provides insight into the public financial commitment to primary education relative to the country's average income level.

Measures the share of total general government expenditure on education that is specifically allocated to the primary level, expressed as a percentage. This indicator is calculated by dividing government spending on primary education by the total government spending on all levels of education combined. It reflects the government's financial priority for primary education relative to other educational levels, such as secondary and tertiary.

Measures the average government expenditure per secondary school student, expressed as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita. It is calculated by dividing total government spending on secondary education (including current, capital, and transfers) by the total number of secondary school students, and then dividing that result by GDP per capita. This indicator reflects the level of public financial investment in secondary education in relation to the country's economic output per person.

Measures the share of total general government expenditure on education that is specifically allocated to the secondary level, expressed as a percentage. This indicator is calculated by dividing government spending on secondary education by the total government spending on all levels of education combined. It indicates the government's financial priority for secondary education in comparison to other educational sectors.

Measures the average government expenditure per tertiary education student, expressed as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita. It is calculated by dividing total government spending on tertiary education (including current, capital, and transfers) by the total number of tertiary students, then dividing that result by GDP per capita. This metric shows the public financial commitment to an individual's higher education relative to the nation's average income.

Measures the share of total general government expenditure on education that is specifically allocated to the tertiary level, expressed as a percentage. This indicator is calculated by dividing government spending on tertiary education by the total government spending on all levels of education combined. It provides insight into the government's financial prioritization of higher education compared to primary and secondary levels.

Measures the total general government expenditure on education (including current, capital, and transfers) as a percentage of total government expenditure across all sectors. This indicator reflects the government's commitment to education by showing the proportion of the national budget allocated to it relative to other public spending areas like health and social services. It includes spending by all levels of government (central, regional, and local).

Measures the total general government expenditure on education (current, capital, and transfers) as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This indicator reflects the country's financial commitment to education in relation to its overall economic output. It includes spending by all levels of government (central, regional, and local) and is a key benchmark for assessing national investment in human capital.

Measures the percentage of currently married women aged 15-49 who report having the final say, either alone or jointly with their partner, across three key areas of household decision-making: their own health care, major household purchases, and visiting family or friends. This indicator is a measure of women's empowerment and autonomy, reflecting their participation in personal, economic, and social choices that affect their lives.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who are married or in a union and make their own informed decisions in three key areas: sexual relations, contraceptive use, and their own reproductive health care. To be counted, a woman must have autonomy in all three domains, meaning she can refuse sexual intercourse, decide on contraception, and decide on her health care. This is a direct measure of bodily autonomy and women's empowerment, and is a key Sustainable Development Goal indicator (5.6.1).

Measures the percentage of seats held by women in a country's national parliament. The calculation is based on the number of seats in the single chamber of a unicameral system or the lower chamber of a bicameral system. This indicator is a widely used measure of women's political participation and access to decision-making at the national level. Upper houses of parliament are not included in this calculation.

Measures how a country's laws and regulations affect women's economic opportunities, scored on a scale from 0 to 100, where 100 represents legal equality with men. The index is an average of scores across eight areas: Mobility, Workplace, Pay, Marriage, Parenthood, Entrepreneurship, Assets, and Pension. It analyzes de jure (formal) laws rather than their de facto implementation, providing a benchmark for progress toward gender equality in the legal framework for business and employment.

Measures the average proportion of a 24-hour day that women devote to unpaid domestic and care work. This work includes activities such as cooking, cleaning, shopping, childcare, and caring for the elderly or sick family members. The indicator is calculated from time-use surveys and serves to quantify the unequal distribution of unpaid labor between genders, which is a key aspect of economic and social inequality.

Measures the average proportion of a 24-hour day that men devote to unpaid domestic and care work. This category of work encompasses tasks such as cooking, cleaning, shopping, childcare, and caring for other household members. Calculated from time-use survey data, this indicator, when compared with the female equivalent, highlights the gender-based division of unpaid labor within a society.

Measures the percentage of ever-partnered women between the ages of 15 and 49 who have experienced physical and/or sexual violence from a current or former intimate partner in the last 12 months. This indicator is a key measure for tracking progress on eliminating intimate partner violence (Sustainable Development Goal 5.2.1). Physical violence includes acts like slapping or hitting, while sexual violence includes forced sexual acts.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife if she argues with him. This indicator, typically sourced from Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), reflects social norms and attitudes towards gender-based violence. It gauges the level of social acceptance of domestic violence as a response to spousal disagreement, which is a significant barrier to women's empowerment and safety.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife if she burns the food. Sourced from surveys like the DHS, this indicator helps assess societal acceptance of domestic violence by measuring attitudes towards physical punishment for perceived failures in domestic roles. It reflects underlying gender norms and the perceived status of women.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife if she goes out without telling him. This indicator, derived from survey data, reflects social norms related to women's autonomy and freedom of movement. An accepting attitude toward this form of violence indicates a lower status for women and acceptance of male control over female partners.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife if she neglects the children. Data is collected through surveys to assess societal attitudes towards domestic violence. This specific reason probes beliefs about gender roles in childcare and whether violence is seen as an acceptable form of punishment for perceived maternal failings.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one of five specified reasons: arguing with him, neglecting the children, going out without telling him, burning the food, or refusing sex. This composite indicator provides an overall measure of the social acceptance of intimate partner violence among women, reflecting prevailing gender norms and attitudes.

Measures the percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe a husband or partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife if she refuses to have sex with him. This indicator, sourced from survey data, specifically assesses attitudes towards sexual autonomy and consent within marriage. Acceptance of violence in this context reflects deeply entrenched gender norms that undermine women's bodily integrity and rights.

Measures the projected total alcohol consumption per female aged 15 and older, expressed in liters of pure alcohol per year. The calculation includes both recorded (officially sold) and unrecorded (e.g., homemade, illicit) alcohol, and is adjusted for tourist consumption. This indicator provides a comprehensive view of alcohol intake among the adult female population, which is crucial for public health monitoring and policy.

Measures the projected total alcohol consumption per capita for individuals aged 15 and older, expressed in liters of pure alcohol per year. This value is a composite of both recorded (officially sold) and unrecorded (e.g., homemade or smuggled) alcohol, adjusted for tourist consumption to reflect national intake accurately. It serves as a key public health indicator for monitoring alcohol-related harm and is part of the Sustainable Development Goals (3.5.2).

Measures the projected total alcohol consumption per male aged 15 and older, expressed in liters of pure alcohol per year. The figure is calculated by summing both recorded (officially sold) and unrecorded (e.g., homemade, illicit) alcohol consumption, with adjustments made for tourism. This gender-disaggregated indicator is essential for understanding patterns of alcohol use and designing targeted public health interventions.

Measures the percentage of women of reproductive age (15-49 years) who are anemic. Anemia is defined based on hemoglobin levels, with the threshold set at less than 11 g/dL for pregnant women and less than 12 g/dL for non-pregnant women. This composite indicator reflects the overall anemia burden in this key demographic. Data is sourced from the World Health Organization (WHO), which uses a Bayesian statistical model to estimate trends from various population-representative surveys.

Measures the percentage of children aged 6 to 59 months who have anemia. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), anemia in this age group is defined as a hemoglobin concentration of less than 110 grams per liter (11 g/dL). The measurement is adjusted for altitude, as higher elevations can naturally increase hemoglobin levels. This indicator is a key measure of child health and nutrition, as anemia can adversely affect cognitive and motor development.

Measures the percentage of non-pregnant women of reproductive age (15-49 years) who are anemic. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines anemia for this specific group as having a hemoglobin concentration of less than 120 grams per liter (12 g/dL) at sea level. This indicator provides a focused assessment of the health status of non-pregnant women, distinguishing their needs and physiological state from those who are pregnant. Estimates are derived using a Bayesian statistical model applied to data from various population surveys.

Represents the percentage of sexually active young women, aged 15 to 24, who reported using a condom during their most recent sexual intercourse within the past 12 months. This indicator is a key measure of safe sexual practices and the adoption of preventative measures against HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Data is primarily collected through self-reported responses in national household surveys such as the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS).

Represents the percentage of sexually active young men, aged 15 to 24, who reported using a condom during their most recent sexual intercourse within the past 12 months. As a key indicator for monitoring safe sex practices, it helps assess the effectiveness of public health campaigns aimed at preventing HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The data is gathered from self-reported answers in household surveys, such as the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS).

Measures the total number of deaths occurring among children aged 5 to 9 years in a given year. This is an absolute count, not a rate. The data is estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), which uses statistical models to harmonize information from various sources, including vital registration systems, censuses, and household surveys. This indicator provides insight into the health and mortality challenges facing school-age children.

Measures the total number of deaths occurring among young adolescents aged 10 to 14 years in a given year. This indicator is reported as an absolute number of deaths, not a rate. Estimates are produced by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) using statistical models that reconcile data from diverse sources like vital registration, surveys, and censuses. It helps in understanding the mortality patterns and health risks for this specific adolescent age group.

Measures the total number of deaths occurring among older adolescents aged 15 to 19 years in a given year. Presented as an absolute count, this indicator is part of a series of age-specific mortality estimates. The data is compiled by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), which employs statistical modeling to create consistent trend lines from various data sources, including vital registration systems and surveys, addressing common data gaps and inconsistencies.

Measures the total number of deaths occurring among young adults aged 20 to 24 years in a given year. This is an absolute count of fatalities within this specific age cohort. The estimates are generated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) through statistical models that synthesize data from national vital registration systems, population censuses, and household surveys to produce reliable and comparable mortality figures.

Measures the share of all deaths in a country that are attributable to communicable diseases and maternal, perinatal, and nutritional conditions, expressed as a percentage of the total number of deaths across all age groups. This broad category includes infectious and parasitic diseases, respiratory infections, and conditions related to pregnancy, childbirth, and malnutrition. The World Health Organization (WHO) compiles and estimates this data using vital registration systems and statistical modeling to ensure international comparability.

Measures the total number of infant deaths occurring before their first birthday in a given year. This is an absolute count, not to be confused with the infant mortality rate. The data is estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), which applies statistical models to data from vital registrations, censuses, and surveys to produce harmonized and internationally comparable figures. It is a fundamental indicator of child health and overall population health.

Measures the proportion of all deaths that are caused by injuries, expressed as a percentage of the total number of deaths in a country. The 'injury' category encompasses both unintentional causes, such as road accidents, falls, and drownings, as well as intentional causes, including violence and self-harm. Data is compiled by the World Health Organization (WHO), which uses statistical models and data from national vital registration systems to estimate cause-of-death distributions.

Measures the total number of children who die before reaching their fifth birthday in a given year. This indicator is an absolute count of under-five deaths. The figures are produced by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), which uses statistical models to synthesize data from various sources like vital registration systems and household surveys. This provides a comprehensive view of child mortality, a key indicator of a country's socio-economic development and health system quality.

Measures the proportion of all deaths attributable to non-communicable diseases (NCDs), expressed as a percentage of total deaths. This category includes chronic conditions such as cardiovascular diseases, cancers, diabetes, chronic respiratory diseases, digestive diseases, and congenital anomalies. The World Health Organization (WHO) compiles these estimates using data from vital registration systems and statistical modeling to account for data gaps and ensure comparability across countries.

Measures the total number of infants who die during the neonatal period, which is defined as the first 28 completed days of life. This is reported as an absolute number of deaths. The data is estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) using statistical models to harmonize figures from various national sources, including vital registration systems and surveys. Neonatal deaths account for a significant portion of child mortality and reflect the quality of perinatal care.

Represents the probability that a child who has reached their 5th birthday will die before reaching their 10th birthday. This mortality rate is expressed per 1,000 children aged 5 and is calculated based on the age-specific mortality rates of the specified year. The estimates are produced by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), providing a standardized measure of mortality risk for school-aged children, assuming current conditions persist.

Represents the probability that an adolescent who has reached their 10th birthday will die before reaching their 15th birthday. This mortality rate is expressed per 1,000 adolescents aged 10, assuming they are subject to the age-specific mortality rates of that year. Produced by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), this indicator measures the risk of death during early adolescence.

Represents the probability that an adolescent who has reached their 15th birthday will die before reaching their 20th birthday. It is expressed as a rate per 1,000 adolescents aged 15 and is based on the prevailing age-specific mortality rates for that year. The data is provided by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) and reflects the mortality risk during late adolescence.

Represents the probability that a young adult who has reached their 20th birthday will die before reaching their 25th birthday. Expressed per 1,000 youths aged 20, this rate is calculated based on the age-specific mortality rates of the specified year. The estimates are generated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) and are used to assess the health risks and mortality patterns among young adults.

Measures the proportion of the adult population (aged 15 and older) living with HIV that is female, expressed as a percentage. This indicator highlights the gender distribution of the HIV epidemic among adults. It is calculated by dividing the number of females aged 15+ living with HIV by the total number of people in the same age group living with HIV. Data is based on estimates from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS).

Measures the percentage of people aged 15 to 49 who are infected with HIV. This indicator provides an estimate of the overall prevalence of HIV within the most sexually active and economically productive age group. The data is compiled by the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), which uses statistical models that incorporate surveillance and survey data to track the course of the epidemic. Low national rates can sometimes mask higher prevalence in specific localities or subgroups.

Measures the probability that a newborn baby will die before reaching their fifth birthday, if subject to the age-specific mortality rates of the specified year. This rate is expressed as the number of deaths per 1,000 live births. It is a critical indicator of child well-being, reflecting a country's health, nutritional, and socio-economic conditions. Estimates are produced by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) to ensure cross-country comparability.

Measures the probability that a newborn female baby will die before reaching her fifth birthday, assuming she is subject to the female age-specific mortality rates of the specified year. This rate is expressed per 1,000 live births. As a sex-disaggregated version of the under-five mortality rate, it is crucial for identifying gender-based disparities in child survival. The data is estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME).

Measures the probability that a newborn male baby will die before reaching his fifth birthday, calculated based on the male age-specific mortality rates for a given year. The rate is expressed per 1,000 live births. This sex-disaggregated indicator helps in assessing gender differences in child mortality, with male mortality typically being slightly higher in early childhood in the absence of gender discrimination. Estimates are compiled by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME).

Represents the probability that a 30-year-old female will die before her 70th birthday from one of four major non-communicable diseases (NCDs): cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease. This is expressed as a percentage. The calculation assumes that she would experience the current age-specific mortality rates for these diseases and would not die from any other cause. The data is based on the World Health Organization's (WHO) Global Health Estimates.

Represents the probability that a 30-year-old male will die before his 70th birthday from one of four major non-communicable diseases (NCDs): cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease. This is expressed as a percentage. The calculation assumes that he would experience the current age-specific mortality rates for these diseases and would not die from any other cause. The data is based on the World Health Organization's (WHO) Global Health Estimates.

Represents the probability that a 30-year-old person will die before their 70th birthday from one of four major non-communicable diseases (NCDs): cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease. This indicator is expressed as a percentage. It is calculated assuming the person would be subject to the current age-specific mortality rates and would not die from other causes. This metric, from the World Health Organization (WHO), is a key indicator for monitoring premature mortality from NCDs.

Measures the number of infants who die during the first 28 days of life per 1,000 live births in a given year. The neonatal mortality rate is a critical indicator of newborn health and the quality of care received by both mothers and infants immediately before, during, and after childbirth. The data is estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) to ensure consistency and comparability across countries.

Measures the percentage of married women of reproductive age (15-49) whose need for family planning is met using modern contraceptive methods. This indicator is calculated as the number of married women using modern methods divided by the total number of married women with a demand for family planning (which includes those currently using any method and those with an unmet need). Modern methods include sterilization, IUDs, injectables, pills, condoms, and implants. Data is primarily from household surveys like the DHS.

Measures the percentage of the rural population that uses at least a basic drinking water service. A 'basic' service is defined as drinking water from an improved source, such as piped water, boreholes, or protected wells, provided the round-trip collection time, including queuing, does not exceed 30 minutes. This indicator also includes the higher tier of 'safely managed' services. Data is compiled by the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) and is a key metric for tracking progress in water access for rural communities.

Measures the share of the urban population that has access to at least basic drinking water services, expressed as a percentage. This category includes users of both 'basic' and the higher-tier 'safely managed' services. A 'basic' service is defined as obtaining drinking water from an improved source, provided the round-trip collection time, including queuing, does not exceed 30 minutes. Improved water sources encompass piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.

Measures the share of the total population that has access to at least basic drinking water services, expressed as a percentage. This indicator encompasses users of both 'basic' and the higher-tier 'safely managed' services. A 'basic' service is defined as using an improved drinking water source where the round-trip collection time, including queuing, is 30 minutes or less. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.

Represents the percentage of the rural population using safely managed drinking water services. This is the highest level of service, defined as using an improved water source that is accessible on the premises, available whenever needed, and free from fecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.

Represents the percentage of the urban population using safely managed drinking water services. This is the highest service level, defined as using an improved water source that is located on the premises, available whenever needed, and free from fecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.

Measures the percentage of the total population using safely managed drinking water services, which represents the highest standard of access. This service is defined as drinking water from an improved source that is accessible on premises, available when needed, and free from fecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved sources include piped water, boreholes, protected wells and springs, and packaged or delivered water.

Indicates the total estimated number of children aged 0 to 14 who are living with HIV. This figure is based on models from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) which track the course of HIV epidemics using a variety of data sources, including surveillance and population surveys, to produce comprehensive estimates.

Measures the prevalence of HIV among young females, expressed as the percentage of the female population aged 15 to 24 who are infected with HIV. The data is based on estimates from UNAIDS, which uses epidemiological models that incorporate surveillance and survey data to track infection rates across different demographic groups.

Measures the prevalence of HIV among young males, expressed as the percentage of the male population aged 15 to 24 who are infected with HIV. These figures are derived from UNAIDS estimates, which rely on epidemiological models that utilize surveillance and survey data to monitor infection trends.

Represents the coverage of antiretroviral therapy (ART), measured as the percentage of all people living with HIV who are receiving the treatment. ART is crucial for reducing mortality and improving the quality of life for those with HIV, as well as for reducing transmission. Data is based on UNAIDS estimates.

Indicates the estimated total number of new HIV infections occurring within a year among adults aged 15 to 49. Because direct measurement of new infections is challenging, this figure is typically generated using mathematical modeling tools, such as Spectrum, which analyze various data sources to estimate incidence rates.

Reports the estimated total number of new HIV infections occurring within a year among children aged 0 to 14. This metric is crucial for monitoring mother-to-child transmission. The estimates are derived from mathematical models that use surveillance, survey, and program data to calculate incidence.

Represents the estimated total number of new HIV infections across all age groups (adults 15 and over, and children 0-14) in a given year. As a measure of the rate of spread of the virus, this indicator is typically estimated using mathematical models that synthesize various data sources, including surveys and surveillance reports.

Measures the incidence rate of HIV, representing the number of new infections occurring in a year for every 1,000 uninfected individuals in the population. This rate provides a standardized measure of the risk of acquiring HIV. The estimates are produced by UNAIDS using the Spectrum modeling software, which incorporates survey, surveillance, and programmatic data.

Indicates the estimated total number of new HIV infections occurring within a year among young people aged 15 to 24. This figure is a key measure for tracking the epidemic in a particularly vulnerable age group and is typically derived from mathematical modeling based on various data inputs.

Measures the incidence rate of HIV among young people, expressed as the number of new infections per 1,000 uninfected individuals aged 15 to 24. This rate provides insight into the speed at which the virus is spreading within this key demographic. The data is based on UNAIDS estimates generated through modeling software.

Measures the incidence rate of HIV among adults, representing the number of new infections per 1,000 uninfected individuals aged 15 to 49. This is a primary indicator for monitoring the HIV epidemic among the adult population. Estimates are produced by UNAIDS using modeling software like Spectrum.

Represents the coverage of antiretroviral therapy for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT). It is measured as the percentage of pregnant women living with HIV who receive antiretroviral medicine. This intervention is critical for reducing the number of newborns infected with HIV. The numerator is based on national program data, while the denominator is estimated via statistical modeling.

Measures the immunization coverage for the third dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine (HepB3) among children. It is expressed as the percentage of children aged 12 to 23 months who have received all three recommended doses. Data is based on WHO and UNICEF estimates, which synthesize administrative records and household survey results.

Measures the immunization coverage for Diphtheria, Pertussis (whooping cough), and Tetanus (DPT). It represents the percentage of children aged 12 to 23 months who have received the recommended three doses of the DPT vaccine. The figure is based on WHO and UNICEF estimates compiled from official country reports and household surveys.

Measures the immunization coverage against measles. It represents the percentage of children aged 12 to 23 months who have received at least one dose of the measles-containing vaccine. Estimates are produced by the WHO and UNICEF based on an assessment of administrative data and household survey information.

Indicates the availability of inpatient services by measuring the number of hospital beds per 1,000 people. The count includes inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals, as well as rehabilitation centers. In most cases, beds for both acute and chronic care are included in the total.

Measures the density of community health workers, expressed as the number of workers per 1,000 people. This category includes various types of community health aides, who may have country-specific titles such as community health officers, family health workers, or health extension package workers. Data is compiled by the WHO from surveys, censuses, and administrative records.

Represents the density of the nursing and midwifery workforce, measured as the number of nurses and midwives per 1,000 people. This includes professional and auxiliary nurses and midwives, enrolled nurses and midwives, and other associated personnel such as dental or primary care nurses. This is a key indicator of health system capacity.

Measures the density of physicians, expressed as the number of physicians per 1,000 people. The count includes both generalist and specialist medical practitioners. This indicator is a core measure of health system human resources, reflecting the availability of medical doctors to the population.

Represents the density of the specialist surgical workforce, measured as the number of specialist surgical, anesthetic, and obstetric (SAO) providers per 100,000 population. This indicator, developed by the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery, helps assess a country's capacity to deliver essential surgical care.

Measures the incidence of malaria, defined as the number of new cases occurring in a year per 1,000 population at risk. The population at risk are those living in areas with malaria transmission. Estimates are adjusted by the WHO to account for factors like underreporting, treatment-seeking behavior, and the accuracy of diagnostic testing.

Measures the use of a key malaria prevention tool, representing the percentage of children under the age of five who slept under an insecticide-treated bed net (ITN) the previous night. Data for this indicator is primarily collected through large-scale household surveys such as Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS).

Measures prompt and effective treatment for malaria in children. It represents the percentage of children under the age of five who had a fever in the two weeks preceding a survey and received any locally appropriate antimalarial drug. This indicator is derived from data collected through household surveys like DHS and MICS.

Represents the total number of maternal deaths in a given year. A maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of the termination of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from accidental or incidental causes. Estimates are produced by the UN Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-Agency Group (MMEIG).

Measures the lifetime risk of maternal death, which is the probability that a 15-year-old female will eventually die from a maternal cause. This indicator is calculated assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) will remain unchanged in the future. It is typically expressed as a ratio of 1 in X, providing an intuitive measure of risk.

Measures the probability that a 15-year-old female will die from a maternal cause during her reproductive life, expressed as a percentage. The calculation assumes that current levels of fertility and mortality, including maternal mortality, remain constant and takes into account other competing causes of death. This indicator provides a comprehensive view of the lifetime risk a woman faces from pregnancy and childbirth-related complications.

Measures the percentage of pregnant women diagnosed with anemia. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), anemia during pregnancy is defined as having a hemoglobin concentration of less than 110 grams per liter (g/L) at sea level. This indicator is crucial for assessing the nutritional and health status of pregnant women, as anemia is linked to adverse maternal and infant outcomes.

Represents the age-standardized percentage of the population aged 15 and over who currently use any form of tobacco. This includes both daily and non-daily use of smoked products (like cigarettes and waterpipes) and smokeless products (like oral and nasal tobacco). The definition explicitly excludes electronic nicotine delivery systems, such as e-cigarettes, that do not contain tobacco. Age-standardization to the WHO Standard Population allows for more reliable comparisons across different countries and time periods.

Represents the age-standardized percentage of the female population aged 15 and over who currently use any form of tobacco. This includes both daily and non-daily use of smoked products (like cigarettes and waterpipes) and smokeless products (like oral and nasal tobacco). The definition explicitly excludes electronic nicotine delivery systems, such as e-cigarettes, that do not contain tobacco. Age-standardization to the WHO Standard Population allows for more reliable comparisons across different countries and time periods.

Represents the age-standardized percentage of the male population aged 15 and over who currently use any form of tobacco. This includes both daily and non-daily use of smoked products (like cigarettes and waterpipes) and smokeless products (like oral and nasal tobacco). The definition explicitly excludes electronic nicotine delivery systems, such as e-cigarettes, that do not contain tobacco. Age-standardization to the WHO Standard Population allows for more reliable comparisons across different countries and time periods.

Measures the percentage of the population at risk of incurring catastrophic expenditure if they require surgical care. Catastrophic expenditure is defined as direct out-of-pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia services that exceed 10% of an individual's or household's total income. This indicator highlights the degree of financial protection people have against the high costs of essential surgical procedures.

Measures the percentage of the population at risk of being pushed into poverty due to the cost of surgical care. Impoverishing expenditure is defined as direct out-of-pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia services that drive a person's income below a specified poverty line (using a threshold of $2.15 PPP per day). This indicator assesses the financial vulnerability of populations when accessing necessary surgical interventions.

Measures the volume of surgical activity within a country, expressed as the number of procedures performed in an operating theatre per 100,000 population annually. A surgical procedure is defined as the incision, excision, or manipulation of tissue requiring regional or general anaesthesia or profound sedation for pain management.
