This indicator serves as a proxy for the capacity and utilization of a nation's surgical healthcare system.

Measures the age-standardized mortality rate for females due to the combined effects of household (indoor) and ambient (outdoor) air pollution, expressed per 100,000 female population. It includes deaths from specific conditions linked to air pollution, such as acute respiratory infections, cerebrovascular diseases, ischaemic heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and lung cancer. Age-standardization enables comparisons across populations with different age structures.

Measures the age-standardized mortality rate for males due to the combined effects of household (indoor) and ambient (outdoor) air pollution, expressed per 100,000 male population. It includes deaths from specific conditions linked to air pollution, such as acute respiratory infections, cerebrovascular diseases, ischaemic heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and lung cancer. Age-standardization enables comparisons across populations with different age structures.

Measures the age-standardized mortality rate for the total population due to the combined effects of household (indoor) and ambient (outdoor) air pollution, expressed per 100,000 population. It includes deaths from specific conditions linked to air pollution, such as acute respiratory infections, cerebrovascular diseases, ischaemic heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and lung cancer. Age-standardization enables comparisons across populations with different age structures.

Measures the percentage of women who have had a live birth and received prenatal (antenatal) care at least once during their pregnancy from skilled health personnel. Skilled health personnel include doctors, nurses, and midwives who provide care for reasons related to the pregnancy. This indicator tracks access to and use of essential maternal healthcare services.

Represents the percentage of children under five years old with symptoms of an acute respiratory infection (ARI) in the preceding two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider. An appropriate health provider includes a range of formal healthcare options such as hospitals, health centers, clinics, village health workers, and private physicians. The indicator reflects care-seeking behavior for a leading cause of childhood illness.

Measures the percentage of the rural population using at least basic sanitation services. This is defined as having access to an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities, designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact, include flush/pour-flush toilets connected to piped sewers or septic tanks, ventilated improved pit latrines, and pit latrines with slabs.

Measures the percentage of the urban population using at least basic sanitation services. This is defined as having access to an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities, designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact, include flush/pour-flush toilets connected to piped sewers or septic tanks, ventilated improved pit latrines, and pit latrines with slabs.

Measures the percentage of the total population using at least basic sanitation services. This is defined as having access to an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities, which are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact, include flush/pour-flush toilets connected to piped sewers or septic tanks, ventilated improved pit latrines, and pit latrines with slabs.

Represents the percentage of infants under six months of age who are exclusively breastfed. Exclusive breastfeeding means the infant received only breast milk in the previous 24 hours, with no other foods or liquids, not even water. The only exceptions are prescribed oral rehydration solution, vitamins, minerals, or medicines. This is a key indicator of optimal infant nutrition and health.

Measures the percentage of live births attended by skilled health personnel. This includes professionally trained doctors, nurses, and midwives who are qualified to provide necessary supervision, care, and advice during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period, as well as conduct deliveries and care for newborns. It is a critical indicator of a health system's capacity to support safe childbirth.

Represents the percentage of live births where the newborn weighs less than 2,500 grams (5.5 pounds). To ensure accuracy, the measurement is taken within the first hour of life, before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred. Low birthweight is a key indicator of maternal health and nutrition and a major determinant of infant mortality and morbidity.

Measures the age-adjusted prevalence of diabetes (both type 1 and type 2) among the population aged 20 to 79, expressed as a percentage. Data is adjusted to a standard population age-structure to account for differences in national age distributions, allowing for more reliable comparisons across countries and over time. This indicator reflects the public health burden of a major chronic disease.

Represents the percentage of girls and women aged 15 to 49 who have undergone female genital mutilation (FGM). FGM includes all procedures that involve the partial or total removal of the external female genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons. This indicator measures the prevalence of a practice recognized internationally as a violation of human rights.

Measures the percentage of the rural population living in households that have a basic handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. A facility can be fixed or mobile (e.g., sink, tippy-tap, basin). Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, or detergent powder, but excludes non-soap agents like ash, soil, or sand. This indicator is a proxy for hygiene practices.

Measures the percentage of the urban population living in households that have a basic handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. A facility can be fixed or mobile (e.g., sink, tippy-tap, basin). Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, or detergent powder, but excludes non-soap agents like ash, soil, or sand. This indicator is a proxy for hygiene practices.

Measures the percentage of the total population living in households that have a basic handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. A facility can be fixed or mobile (e.g., sink, tippy-tap, basin). Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, or detergent powder, but excludes non-soap agents like ash, soil, or sand. This indicator is a proxy for hygiene practices.

Measures the percentage of girls under five years of age who are underweight. A child is classified as underweight if her weight-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards. This indicator reflects both acute (wasting) and chronic (stunting) malnutrition and is a key measure of child nutritional status.

Measures the percentage of boys under five years of age who are underweight. A child is classified as underweight if his weight-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards. This indicator reflects both acute (wasting) and chronic (stunting) malnutrition and is a key measure of child nutritional status.

Measures the percentage of children under five years of age who are underweight. A child is classified as underweight if their weight-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards. This indicator reflects both acute (wasting) and chronic (stunting) malnutrition and is a key measure of child nutritional status.

Represents the number of female deaths from any cause related to or aggravated by pregnancy or its management (excluding accidental or incidental causes) during pregnancy and childbirth or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, expressed per 100,000 live births. This is a modeled estimate derived from a regression model using various socioeconomic and health-related data to ensure comparability across countries.

Represents the number of female deaths from any cause related to or aggravated by pregnancy or its management during pregnancy and childbirth or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, expressed per 100,000 live births. This indicator is based on data collected through national systems, such as civil registration, household surveys, or other administrative records, rather than a global statistical model.

Measures the percentage of the rural population that practices open defecation. This is defined as defecating in open spaces such as fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, or beaches, rather than using a toilet or latrine. This practice represents the most basic lack of sanitation and poses significant public health and environmental risks.

Measures the percentage of the urban population that practices open defecation. This practice includes defecating in open environments such as fields, forests, bushes, bodies of water, or beaches, as well as disposing of human feces with solid waste. Data is primarily sourced from household surveys and censuses, with estimates compiled by the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP). This indicator represents the lowest level in the JMP's sanitation service ladder and is a key metric for assessing public health and dignity in urban settings.

Measures the percentage of a country's total population that practices open defecation. This practice is defined as defecating in open spaces like fields, forests, bushes, bodies of water, or beaches, or disposing of human feces with solid waste. The data is compiled by the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) from sources like household surveys and censuses. As the lowest tier on the sanitation ladder, this indicator is critical for monitoring progress towards Sustainable Development Goal 6.2, which aims to end open defecation.

Measures the percentage of children under the age of five who experienced diarrhea in the two weeks preceding a survey and received appropriate treatment. This treatment is defined as receiving either oral rehydration therapy (ORT) or increased fluids, combined with continued feeding. Data is collected through household surveys, such as the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), by questioning mothers or caregivers. The indicator assesses the coverage of a key life-saving intervention for childhood diarrhea.

Represents the percentage of children under five years old who had diarrhea in the two weeks before a survey and were treated with oral rehydration salts (ORS). This includes the administration of ORS from packets or pre-packaged ORS fluids. The data is gathered from household surveys where caregivers report on the child's recent health and treatments received. This indicator specifically tracks the use of a manufactured, effective remedy for dehydration caused by diarrhea.

Measures the prevalence of overweight among female children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A girl is classified as overweight if her weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations above the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards from 2006. This indicator, derived from national survey data, reflects acute over-nutrition and is a key measure of childhood health and the risk of future noncommunicable diseases.

Measures the prevalence of overweight among male children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A boy is classified as overweight if his weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations above the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards from 2006. Sourced from national survey data, this indicator reflects acute over-nutrition and is used to monitor childhood health and associated long-term health risks.

Provides a modeled estimate of the prevalence of overweight among female children under five, expressed as a percentage. Overweight is defined as a weight-for-height that is more than two standard deviations above the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). These estimates are produced by the UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group using statistical models to provide consistent and comparable figures, especially for countries with infrequent survey data.

Provides a modeled estimate of the prevalence of overweight among male children under five, expressed as a percentage. A boy is considered overweight if his weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations above the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). These figures are generated by the UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group through statistical modeling to ensure comparability and fill gaps in national survey data.

Presents a modeled estimate of the prevalence of overweight among all children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A child is defined as overweight if their weight-for-height measurement is more than two standard deviations above the median set by the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). This indicator is produced by the Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank) using statistical models to create comparable time-series data and address gaps left by irregular national surveys.

Measures the prevalence of overweight among children under five, expressed as a percentage, based on direct national survey data. A child is classified as overweight if their weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations above the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). This indicator reflects acute over-nutrition and serves as a fundamental measure of childhood health status before statistical modeling is applied for international comparison.

Measures the annual number of deaths resulting from unintentional poisonings, expressed per 100,000 population. This includes fatalities caused by accidental exposure to substances such as household chemicals, pesticides, kerosene, carbon monoxide, and medicines, as well as environmental or occupational chemical exposure. The data is based on the WHO Global Health Estimates, which utilize vital registration systems or statistical modeling for countries without high-quality data.

Measures the annual number of female deaths due to unintentional poisonings, expressed per 100,000 female population. Unintentional poisoning can result from exposure to household chemicals, pesticides, medicines, carbon monoxide, or environmental and occupational hazards. These estimates are derived from the WHO Global Health Estimates, which use a combination of vital registration data and statistical modeling to ensure cross-country comparability.

Measures the annual number of male deaths attributed to unintentional poisonings, expressed per 100,000 male population. This category includes deaths from accidental exposure to substances like household chemicals, pesticides, medicines, and carbon monoxide, as well as environmental or occupational chemicals. The data comes from the WHO Global Health Estimates, which rely on vital registration systems where available and statistical models otherwise.

Measures the percentage of the rural population using safely managed sanitation services. This is defined as using an improved sanitation facility (such as a flush toilet connected to a sewer, septic tank, or pit latrine) that is not shared with other households and where human waste is safely disposed of on-site or transported and treated off-site. This indicator represents the highest standard on the WHO/UNICEF JMP sanitation ladder, reflecting access to both adequate facilities and safe waste management in rural areas.

Measures the percentage of the urban population using safely managed sanitation services. This standard requires the use of an improved sanitation facility (e.g., flush toilet connected to a sewer, septic tank, or pit latrine) that is not shared with other households and ensures that excreta are either safely treated and disposed of in situ or are transported and treated off-site. As the highest level on the WHO/UNICEF JMP sanitation ladder, it assesses access to adequate and safe sanitation in urban settings.

Measures the percentage of the total population using safely managed sanitation services, which is the highest level of service defined by the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP). This requires using an improved sanitation facility (like a flush toilet) that is not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of on-site or treated off-site. This comprehensive indicator is a key measure for Sustainable Development Goal 6.2, reflecting both access to facilities and the safe management of waste.

Measures the prevalence of stunting among female children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A girl is considered stunted if her height-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards from 2006. Based on national survey data, this indicator is a measure of chronic malnutrition and reflects long-term nutritional deprivation and its impact on growth.

Measures the prevalence of stunting among male children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A boy is classified as stunted if his height-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards from 2006. Derived from national surveys, this indicator reflects chronic malnutrition and is a key marker of long-term health and developmental outcomes.

Provides a modeled estimate of the prevalence of stunting among female children under five, expressed as a percentage. Stunting is defined as a height-for-age that is more than two standard deviations below the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). These figures are produced by the UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group using statistical models to provide consistent and comparable data, particularly for countries with infrequent national surveys.

Provides a modeled estimate of the prevalence of stunting among male children under five, expressed as a percentage. Stunting is defined as a height-for-age that is more than two standard deviations below the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). These estimates are generated by the UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group through statistical modeling to ensure data consistency and fill gaps from national surveys.

Presents a modeled estimate of the prevalence of stunting among all children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A child is considered stunted if their height-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median set by the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). This indicator is produced by the Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates (JME) group (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank) using statistical models to create comparable time-series data on chronic malnutrition.

Measures the prevalence of stunting among children under five, expressed as a percentage, based on direct national survey data. A child is classified as stunted if their height-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006). This indicator is a key measure of chronic malnutrition and serves as the primary data source before statistical modeling is applied for international comparisons.

Measures the annual number of deaths by suicide among females, expressed as a crude rate per 100,000 female population. This rate is not adjusted for age distribution. The data is derived from the WHO Global Health Estimates, which utilize official vital registration records from countries where available and employ statistical models to estimate rates for other countries, ensuring international comparability.

Measures the annual number of deaths by suicide among males, expressed as a crude rate per 100,000 male population. This indicator is not adjusted for differences in age structure. The estimates are produced by the WHO Global Health Estimates program, which relies on national vital registration data when available and uses statistical models to generate figures for countries lacking such data.

Represents the number of suicide deaths in a given year per 100,000 people in the total population. This is a crude mortality rate, meaning it is not adjusted for the age structure of the population. The indicator is based on the WHO Global Health Estimates, which compile data from national vital registration systems or use statistical models to estimate mortality for countries where high-quality data is unavailable.

Measures the estimated number of deaths resulting from road traffic injuries, expressed per 100,000 population. This indicator covers fatalities from crashes involving vehicles, pedestrians, and cyclists. Data is compiled by the World Health Organization, which uses country-level vital registration systems where possible and statistical modeling based on various data sources for countries with incomplete records. This is the key indicator for Sustainable Development Goal 3.6.1.

Measures the number of deaths per 100,000 population that can be attributed to exposure to unsafe water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH). The estimate is calculated using a comparative risk assessment methodology and primarily includes deaths from diarrheal diseases, intestinal nematode infections, and protein-energy malnutrition that are linked to inadequate WASH conditions. It serves as a key indicator for Sustainable Development Goal 3.9.2, tracking the health impact of environmental risk factors.

Measures the prevalence of wasting among female children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A girl is considered wasted if her weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations below the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards. Wasting is an indicator of acute malnutrition, reflecting recent and severe weight loss, often due to starvation or disease. Data is derived from national surveys.

Measures the prevalence of wasting among male children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. A boy is classified as wasted if his weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations below the median established by the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards. This indicator captures acute malnutrition, often caused by recent illness or food shortages, and is based on data from national surveys.

Measures the prevalence of wasting among all children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. Wasting, an indicator of acute malnutrition, is defined as a weight-for-height more than two standard deviations below the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The data, collected through national surveys, reflects the proportion of children who are dangerously thin, often as a result of recent rapid weight loss or failure to gain weight.

Measures the percentage of female children under the age of five who are suffering from severe wasting, a form of acute malnutrition where a child is too thin for their height. The prevalence is calculated based on the proportion of girls whose weight-for-height measurement is more than three standard deviations below the median of the international reference population, as defined by the WHO Child Growth Standards. Data is typically collected through national surveys and reflects a critical aspect of child nutritional status and immediate mortality risk.

Measures the percentage of male children under the age of five who are suffering from severe wasting, a form of acute malnutrition characterized by being dangerously thin for one's height. The prevalence is determined by the proportion of boys whose weight-for-height is more than three standard deviations below the median of the international reference population, as established by the WHO Child Growth Standards. This indicator, based on national survey data, is a key measure of acute nutritional deficiencies and child health.

Represents the prevalence of severe wasting among all children under the age of five, expressed as a percentage. It measures the proportion of children (both male and female) whose weight-for-height is more than three standard deviations below the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Wasting indicates recent and severe weight loss, often due to acute starvation or disease, and is a critical indicator of nutritional status and immediate mortality risk in young children.

Measures the percentage of new tuberculosis (TB) cases registered under a national control program in a given year that were successfully treated. Treatment success is a composite outcome, including cases that were bacteriologically confirmed as "cured" and those who "completed treatment" without bacteriological confirmation. This indicator reflects the quality and effectiveness of a country's health services in managing TB. Cases that result in treatment failure, death, or are lost to follow-up are excluded from the success rate.

Represents the case detection rate for all forms of tuberculosis (TB), expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of new and relapse TB cases officially notified to the World Health Organization (WHO) in a given year by the WHO's estimate of the total number of incident cases for that same year. This indicator helps gauge the effectiveness of a country's TB surveillance and diagnostic services in identifying the actual number of people who fall ill with the disease.

Measures the incidence of tuberculosis (TB), representing the estimated number of new and relapse cases arising in a given year. The rate is expressed per 100,000 population. This indicator includes all forms of TB, including cases among people living with HIV. As direct measurement is difficult, the World Health Organization produces these estimates based on a combination of national surveillance data, prevalence surveys, and epidemiological modeling. It is a key indicator for Sustainable Development Goal 3.3.2.

Measures the percentage of the population living in households that are already below the $2.15 a day (2017 PPP) international poverty line and are pushed even further into poverty due to any out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. This indicator captures the deepening of poverty caused by direct payments for healthcare, where any health spending by an already poor household is considered a financial hardship. It reflects the vulnerability of the poorest populations to health-related financial shocks.

Measures the percentage of the population living in households that are already below the $3.65 a day (2017 PPP) international poverty line and are pushed further into poverty due to out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. This indicator highlights the financial hardship and deepening poverty experienced by people below this specific poverty threshold when they have to pay directly for health services. Any OOP health payment by these households is considered to exacerbate their poverty.

Measures the percentage of the population living in households that are already below the relative poverty line (defined as 60% of median household consumption) and are pushed even further into poverty by out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. This indicator assesses the deepening of poverty caused by direct healthcare payments relative to a country's specific income distribution. It identifies the portion of the relatively poor population for whom any OOP health spending constitutes an additional financial hardship.

Measures the percentage of the population that is pushed below the $2.15 a day (2017 PPP) international poverty line as a direct result of out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. This indicator identifies individuals in households that would have been above the poverty line if they did not have to pay for healthcare but fell below it after incurring these costs. It quantifies the impoverishing impact of direct health payments and is a key metric for assessing financial protection in health.

Measures the percentage of the population that is pushed below the $3.65 a day (2017 PPP) international poverty line due to out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. It is calculated for households whose consumption would have been above this poverty line before health spending but dropped below it afterward. This indicator provides insight into the extent to which direct healthcare payments create poverty at a higher poverty threshold, reflecting a lack of financial protection.

Measures the percentage of the population that is pushed below the relative poverty line (defined as 60% of median household consumption) as a direct result of out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures. This indicator identifies individuals in households whose consumption was above this relative poverty threshold before paying for health care but fell below it after. It assesses the impoverishing effect of OOP payments in the context of a country's own income distribution.

Measures the percentage of the population living in households where out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures exceed 10% of the total household consumption or income. This is a measure of "catastrophic" health spending, which indicates a level of financial burden that can force households to sacrifice other basic needs. This indicator is part of the monitoring framework for Sustainable Development Goal 3.8.2 on financial protection.

Measures the percentage of the population living in households where out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures exceed 25% of the total household consumption or income. This indicator captures a more severe level of "catastrophic" health spending, signifying a significant financial strain that compromises a household's ability to maintain its basic living standards. It is a key metric for tracking progress towards universal health coverage and financial protection (SDG 3.8.2).

Represents the Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index, which measures the average coverage of essential health services on a scale from 0 to 100. The index is calculated as a geometric mean of tracer indicators organized into four main categories: reproductive, maternal, and child health; infectious diseases; noncommunicable diseases; and service capacity and access. It provides a summary measure of a country's progress in ensuring its population receives key health services, and it is the official indicator for Sustainable Development Goal 3.8.1.

Measures the total percentage of the population experiencing medical impoverishment relative to the $2.15 a day (2017 PPP) poverty line. This composite indicator includes two groups: those pushed below the poverty line by out-of-pocket (OOP) health payments, and those who were already below the poverty line and were pushed even further into poverty by any OOP spending. It provides a comprehensive view of the share of the population facing financial hardship from healthcare costs at this poverty threshold.

Measures the total percentage of the population experiencing medical impoverishment relative to the $3.65 a day (2017 PPP) poverty line. This indicator combines the proportion of the population pushed below this poverty line by out-of-pocket (OOP) health expenditures with the proportion that was already below the line and was driven deeper into poverty by these costs. It offers a broad assessment of financial hardship due to healthcare payments at a higher poverty line.

Measures the total percentage of the population experiencing medical impoverishment relative to the national poverty line, defined as 60% of median household consumption. This composite indicator sums two groups: the population pushed below this relative poverty line by out-of-pocket (OOP) health spending, and the population already below it that is pushed even further into poverty. It provides a comprehensive measure of financial hardship from healthcare costs within the context of a country's specific living standards.

Measures the percentage of newborns protected against tetanus at birth, which is achieved through the immunization of their mothers. The indicator reflects the proportion of births to women of child-bearing age who have received the necessary tetanus toxoid vaccinations to confer immunity to their newborns. Data is based on assessments by the WHO and UNICEF, which combine administrative records and household survey results to estimate coverage. This is a key indicator for maternal and neonatal health.

Represents the total current expenditure on health from all sources, both public and private, expressed as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This indicator reflects the overall economic resources a country devotes to health care consumption in a given year. It is based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework and excludes capital investments in the health sector, such as the construction of new hospitals and machinery.

Measures the average amount spent on health per person in a country, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This is calculated by dividing the total current health expenditure by the mid-year population. The data, compiled under the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework, includes spending on all healthcare goods and services consumed within the year but excludes capital health investments. It provides a measure of the level of health spending relative to population size.

Measures the average amount spent on health per person in a country, expressed in current international dollars and adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP conversion eliminates differences in price levels between countries, allowing for more meaningful cross-country comparisons of health spending. This indicator is based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework and reflects the consumption of healthcare goods and services, excluding capital investments.

Represents the share of a country's current health expenditure that is funded by external sources, expressed as a percentage. These sources include direct foreign transfers and foreign aid that are channeled through either the government or non-governmental organizations. The indicator, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011), shows the degree to which a country's health system relies on international financing to cover its consumption of healthcare goods and services.

Measures the per capita health expenditure that is funded by external sources, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This is calculated by dividing the total financial inflows for health from outside the country by the mid-year population. It reflects the average amount of international aid and other foreign funding for health available per person in a given year, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework.

Measures the per capita health expenditure from external sources, expressed in current international dollars and adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). This PPP adjustment accounts for differences in price levels between countries, enabling a more accurate comparison of the real value of international health funding per person. It is calculated by dividing total external health funds by the population, following the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework.

Measures the share of current health expenditure that is funded from domestic general government sources, expressed as a percentage. These sources include internal transfers from government revenue, social security contributions, and other compulsory prepayments for health. This indicator specifically excludes external funds, such as international aid, that may be channeled through the government, thereby reflecting the government's commitment to funding healthcare from its own domestic resources.

Represents domestic general government health expenditure as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This indicator measures the size of public health spending that originates from domestic sources relative to the size of the national economy. It reflects the government's financial commitment to the health sector using its own resources, excluding any international aid that may be channeled through the public budget.

Measures domestic general government health expenditure as a percentage of total general government expenditure. This indicator shows the priority given to health in the national budget, reflecting what proportion of public spending from domestic sources is allocated to the health sector. It provides insight into the government's policy focus on health relative to other sectors, using domestically generated funds.

Measures the per capita health expenditure from domestic general government sources, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This is calculated by dividing the total public spending on health that originates from domestic revenues by the mid-year population. The indicator reflects the average amount of domestically-funded public money spent on health for each person, providing a measure of the government's direct financial contribution to individual healthcare.

Measures the per capita health expenditure from domestic general government sources, expressed in current international dollars and adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). The PPP conversion allows for more accurate international comparisons by accounting for differences in price levels. This indicator represents the real value of domestically-funded public health spending per person, reflecting the government's financial capacity to provide health services to its citizens.

Measures the share of a country's total current health expenditure that is paid directly by households, expressed as a percentage. Out-of-pocket payments are direct expenditures made by individuals and families for healthcare services and goods at the time of use. This indicator, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework, is crucial for assessing financial protection in healthcare and monitoring progress towards universal health coverage by highlighting the financial burden placed on households.

Represents the average out-of-pocket health expenditure per person in a country, measured in current U.S. dollars. This is calculated by dividing the total direct health spending by households by the country's midyear population. The data, compiled using the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) methodology, reflects the average financial contribution individuals make towards their healthcare costs, serving as a key metric for evaluating financial protection and progress towards universal health coverage.

Measures the average out-of-pocket health expenditure per person, expressed in current international dollars adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). This per capita figure is calculated by dividing total direct household spending on health by the population and converting it using PPP rates. This adjustment accounts for differences in the cost of living between countries, allowing for more meaningful international comparisons of the financial burden of healthcare on individuals. Data is based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework.

Measures the proportion of a country's total current health expenditure that is funded by domestic private sources, expressed as a percentage. These private sources include direct out-of-pocket payments by households, prepaid contributions to voluntary health insurance schemes, and spending by corporations and non-profit organizations. The indicator, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011), provides insight into the structure of a country's health financing system and the role of the private sector.

Represents the average domestic private health expenditure per person, measured in current U.S. dollars. This is calculated by dividing the total health spending from private sources—including households, corporations, and non-profits—by the midyear population. The figure covers both direct payments to providers and prepayments to voluntary health insurance schemes. It provides a per capita view of the private sector's financial contribution to healthcare, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011).

Measures the average domestic private health expenditure per person, expressed in current international dollars and adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). This per capita figure is calculated by dividing total private health spending by the population and converting it using PPP rates. By accounting for cross-country differences in the cost of living, this indicator allows for more accurate international comparisons of private health spending. It includes spending from households, corporations, and non-profits, based on the System of Health Accounts (SHA 2011) framework.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that accrues to the second quintile of the population. The population is ranked from poorest to richest based on per capita income or consumption and divided into five equal groups. This indicator represents the share held by the group from the 21st to the 40th percentile. It is derived from nationally representative household surveys and is a key metric for analyzing income distribution and inequality, focusing on the lower-middle segment of the population.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that is held by the third quintile of the population. After ranking the population by per capita income or consumption, this indicator captures the share belonging to the middle 20% (the 41st to 60th percentiles). The data is sourced from nationally representative household surveys and provides insight into the economic standing of the middle class, which is essential for understanding overall income distribution and economic stability.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that accrues to the fourth quintile of the population. When the population is ordered by per capita income or consumption, this indicator represents the share held by the upper-middle 20% (the 61st to 80th percentiles). Based on data from national household surveys, this metric is used to analyze the distribution of wealth and understand the economic position of the segment just below the highest earners.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that is held by the highest quintile of the population. This indicator represents the share accruing to the wealthiest 20% of individuals, based on a ranking of per capita income or consumption from national household surveys. It is a critical measure of economic concentration and is widely used to assess the extent of inequality within a country by showing how much wealth is controlled by the top earners.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that accrues to the highest decile of the population. This indicator represents the share held by the wealthiest 10% of individuals, based on a ranking of per capita income or consumption from national household surveys. It provides a more focused view of wealth concentration at the very top of the distribution, serving as a key indicator for analyzing extreme economic inequality.

Measures the percentage of the population with a per capita income or consumption level below 50% of the national median. This indicator provides a measure of relative poverty, identifying the share of people whose economic resources are significantly lower than the typical standard of living in their society. The median is adjusted using 2021 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) dollars to allow for standardized comparisons. It highlights inequality at the lower end of the distribution and is particularly relevant for assessing social exclusion.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that accrues to the lowest decile of the population. This indicator represents the share held by the poorest 10% of individuals, based on a ranking of per capita income or consumption from national household surveys. It is a direct measure of the economic well-being of the most vulnerable segment of society and is critical for assessing the extent of poverty and the effectiveness of poverty-alleviation policies.

Measures the percentage share of a country's total income or consumption that is held by the lowest quintile of the population. After ranking the population by per capita income or consumption, this indicator captures the share belonging to the poorest 20%. The data is derived from national household surveys and is a fundamental measure for monitoring poverty and inequality, reflecting the economic resources available to the most disadvantaged group in society.

Measures the percentage of a country's population living on less than $3.00 a day. This international poverty line is measured in 2021 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) U.S. dollars to ensure comparability across countries by adjusting for differences in the cost of living. Based on household consumption or income data, this indicator reflects the prevalence of extreme poverty, typically defined by the standards of the world's poorest countries. It is a core metric for monitoring progress towards global poverty reduction goals, including Sustainable Development Goal 1.

Measures the depth of poverty by indicating the average shortfall of the poor's income or consumption from the international poverty line of $3.00 a day (2021 PPP). It is calculated as the mean distance below the poverty line across the entire population, with the non-poor counted as having a shortfall of zero, and is expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This metric goes beyond the simple headcount ratio by reflecting how far, on average, the poor are from escaping poverty, thus providing a measure of the severity of poverty.

Measures the extent to which the distribution of income or consumption expenditure among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. The Gini index is calculated based on the Lorenz curve and is scaled from 0 (perfect equality) to 100 (perfect inequality). A higher Gini index indicates greater inequality, meaning that income is highly concentrated among a small portion of the population. It is the most widely used summary measure for tracking changes in income or consumption inequality over time and across countries.

Measures the percentage of a country's population living on less than $4.20 a day. This international poverty line, measured in 2021 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) U.S. dollars, is representative of the national poverty lines in lower-middle-income countries. It provides a benchmark for assessing poverty in countries that have moved beyond extreme poverty but still face significant challenges. The indicator is based on household consumption or income data and is used to monitor poverty levels with a standard appropriate for this income group.

Measures the depth of poverty relative to the $4.20 a day poverty line (2021 PPP), which is typical for lower-middle-income countries. It represents the mean shortfall of the poor's income or consumption from this poverty line, expressed as a percentage of the line itself. The calculation averages the gap across the entire population, counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall. This indicator provides insight into the severity of poverty, showing how far below the lower-middle-income standard the poor population lives.

Measures the percentage of the population living in acute multidimensional poverty, according to the methodology developed by the UNDP and OPHI. This indicator goes beyond monetary poverty to capture overlapping deprivations a person faces across three dimensions: health, education, and living standards. These dimensions are assessed using 10 indicators, including nutrition, child mortality, years of schooling, and access to basic services like electricity and clean water. A person is identified as multidimensionally poor if they are deprived in at least one-third of the weighted indicators.

Measures the percentage of the population living in multidimensional poverty, as defined by the World Bank's Multidimensional Poverty Measure (MPM). This measure complements monetary poverty by incorporating deprivations in education and access to basic infrastructure. It assesses poverty across three dimensions: monetary (income below $3.00/day), education (attainment and enrollment), and basic services (access to electricity, sanitation, and safe drinking water). An individual is considered multidimensionally poor if they are deprived in a combination of indicators equivalent in weight to one full dimension.

Measures the percentage of the population living below the official national poverty line(s) as defined by each country's government. These country-specific poverty lines are based on national economic and social circumstances and reflect local perceptions of the income or consumption level required to meet basic needs. Because the definition of the poverty line varies from country to country, this indicator is not suitable for international comparisons but is essential for monitoring poverty according to a country's own standards and for guiding national policies.

Measures the percentage of the population living below the Societal Poverty Line (SPL), a measure that combines absolute and relative poverty concepts. The SPL is defined as the greater of two values: the international extreme poverty line of $3.00 per day, or a relative line set at $1.30 plus 50% of the country's median income or consumption per day (all in 2021 PPP dollars). This approach ensures a basic minimum standard while also reflecting that the cost of social inclusion rises as a country's overall prosperity increases, making it a relevant measure across different levels of economic development.

Measures the percentage of a country's population living on less than $8.30 a day. This international poverty line, measured in 2021 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) U.S. dollars, is representative of the national poverty lines in upper-middle-income countries. It provides a poverty benchmark that is more relevant for countries with higher average incomes than the extreme poverty line. The indicator is based on household consumption or income data and is used to assess poverty levels against a standard appropriate for this income group.

Measures the depth of poverty relative to the $8.30 a day poverty line (2021 PPP), which is typical for upper-middle-income countries. It represents the mean shortfall of the poor's income or consumption from this poverty line, expressed as a percentage of the line itself. The calculation averages this gap across the entire population, counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall. This metric quantifies the severity of poverty by showing how far, on average, the poor population is from reaching the upper-middle-income poverty standard.

Measures the average total cost of sending remittances to a specific recipient country, expressed as a percentage of the amount sent. The calculation is based on the simple average of the costs charged by all remittance service providers (RSPs) in the World Bank's Remittance Prices Worldwide database for a transaction of USD 200. This indicator helps monitor the cost of inbound remittances and is relevant for understanding the financial barriers faced by those receiving funds from abroad. A lower cost means more money reaches the recipients.

Measures the average total cost of sending remittances from a specific country, expressed as a percentage of the amount sent. This figure is the simple average of costs charged by all remittance service providers (RSPs) included in the World Bank's Remittance Prices Worldwide database for sending USD 200 from that country. This indicator is crucial for tracking progress towards global targets for reducing remittance costs, such as those outlined in the Sustainable Development Goals, as lower costs increase the disposable income of migrants and their families.

Measures the average daily consumption or income per person for the bottom 40% of the population, expressed in 2021 international dollars adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). This indicator is calculated from household survey data and provides a direct measure of the economic well-being of the less well-off segment of society. It is a core component for calculating the shared prosperity premium, which tracks whether growth is benefiting the poorest.

Represents the annualized average growth rate of per capita real consumption or income for the bottom 40% of the population. This indicator is calculated by comparing the mean welfare of this group between two household surveys over a period of approximately five years. It is a key measure of 'shared prosperity,' indicating whether economic growth is inclusive and is improving the living standards of the less well-off segment of society. A positive growth rate signifies that the bottom 40% are seeing their economic situation improve over time.

Measures the average daily consumption or income per person for the total population of a country, expressed in 2021 international dollars adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). This figure is derived from nationally representative household survey data and serves as a broad indicator of the average standard of living. It is often used as a baseline to compare against the welfare of specific subgroups, such as the bottom 40%, to assess the inclusiveness of economic growth.

Measures the annualized average growth rate of real per capita consumption or income for the total population, expressed as a percentage. The calculation is based on data from comparable household surveys conducted over an approximate 5-year period, with monetary values adjusted to 2021 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) dollars. This indicator reflects the rate of change in the economic well-being of the average person in a country, calculated using a compound growth formula between two survey points.

Measures the average shortfall from a prosperity standard of $28 per day (in 2021 PPP dollars), representing the average factor by which individual incomes would need to increase to reach this standard. This is a distribution-sensitive metric, meaning that income growth for the poorest individuals contributes more significantly to reducing the gap. Data is derived from nationally representative household surveys. A smaller gap indicates greater shared prosperity within a society.

Measures the share of economically active female children, ages 7 to 14, who are employed in the agriculture sector. It is expressed as a percentage of all economically active females in that age group. A child is considered 'economically active' for engaging in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The agriculture sector, defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing. This indicator helps track the sectoral distribution of child employment.

Measures the share of economically active male children, ages 7 to 14, who are employed in the agriculture sector. It is expressed as a percentage of all economically active males in that age group. A child is considered 'economically active' for engaging in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The agriculture sector, defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing. This indicator helps track the sectoral distribution of child employment.

Measures the share of all economically active children, ages 7 to 14, who are employed in the agriculture sector. It is expressed as a percentage of all economically active children in that age group. A child is considered 'economically active' if they were engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The agriculture sector is defined according to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) and includes farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing.

Represents the proportion of a country's total female employment that is in the agriculture sector, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The agriculture sector, as defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes activities in farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing. 'Employment' refers to all persons of working age engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit.

Represents the proportion of a country's total male employment that is in the agriculture sector, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The agriculture sector, as defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes activities in farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing. 'Employment' refers to all persons of working age engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit.

Represents the proportion of a country's total employment that is in the agriculture sector, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The agriculture sector, as defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes activities in farming, hunting, forestry, and fishing. 'Employment' refers to all persons of working age engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit.

Measures the proportion of a country's female population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a national estimate, typically derived from labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator reflects the economy's capacity to provide employment for young women.

Measures the proportion of a country's female population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), which includes both nationally reported and imputed data. 'Employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. The indicator reflects the economy's ability to provide employment for young women.

Measures the proportion of a country's male population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a national estimate, typically derived from labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator reflects the economy's capacity to provide employment for young men.

Measures the proportion of a country's male population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), which includes both nationally reported and imputed data. 'Employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. The indicator reflects the economy's ability to provide employment for young men.

Measures the proportion of a country's total population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a national estimate, typically derived from labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator reflects the economy's capacity to provide employment for young people.

Measures the proportion of a country's total population aged 15-24 that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that specific population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), which includes both nationally reported and imputed data. 'Employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. The indicator reflects the economy's ability to provide employment for young people.

Represents the share of female employment classified as employers, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Employers are defined as self-employed individuals who, on a continuous basis, hire one or more persons to work for them as employees. This indicator helps to understand the structure of the labor market and the prevalence of female entrepreneurship involving job creation.

Represents the share of male employment classified as employers, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Employers are defined as self-employed individuals who, on a continuous basis, hire one or more persons to work for them as employees. This indicator helps to understand the structure of the labor market and the prevalence of male entrepreneurship involving job creation.

Represents the share of total employment classified as employers, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Employers are defined as self-employed individuals who, on a continuous basis, hire one or more persons to work for them as employees. This indicator provides insight into the structure of the labor market and the level of entrepreneurship that involves job creation.

Measures the share of female employment that is classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The self-employed category includes employers, own-account workers, members of producers' cooperatives, and contributing family workers. This indicator provides insight into the prevalence of non-wage employment among women, which is often a feature of the informal sector.

Measures the share of male employment that is classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The self-employed category includes employers, own-account workers, members of producers' cooperatives, and contributing family workers. This indicator provides insight into the prevalence of non-wage employment among men.

Measures the share of total employment that is classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The self-employed category is broad, encompassing employers, own-account workers, members of producers' cooperatives, and contributing family workers. This indicator provides insight into the structure of a country's labor market and the prevalence of non-wage employment.

Measures the number of women in senior and middle management positions as a percentage of the total number of people employed in those roles. Management occupations are defined according to the International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO). This indicator specifically focuses on higher-level management and excludes junior management positions, providing a measure of women's access to leadership and decision-making roles within the economy.

Measures the proportion of a country's female population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a national estimate, typically based on data from national labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator shows the economy's ability to provide jobs for the working-age female population.

Measures the proportion of a country's female population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), combining national data with imputations for missing values. According to the ILO definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. It reflects the economy's ability to provide jobs for the working-age female population.

Measures the proportion of a country's male population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a national estimate, typically based on data from national labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator shows the economy's ability to provide jobs for the working-age male population.

Measures the proportion of a country's male population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), combining national data with imputations for missing values. According to the ILO definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. It reflects the economy's ability to provide jobs for the working-age male population.

Measures the proportion of a country's population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a national estimate, typically based on data from national labor force surveys. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO) definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This indicator provides a broad picture of an economy's ability to create employment for its working-age population.

Measures the proportion of a country's population aged 15 and over that is employed, expressed as a percentage of that population group. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), combining national data with imputations for missing values. According to the ILO definition, 'employed' refers to individuals who performed at least one hour of work for pay or profit during a specified reference period. This provides a broad picture of an economy's ability to create employment.

Measures the share of female employment that is classified as vulnerable, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Vulnerable employment is the sum of own-account workers (self-employed workers who do not hire employees) and contributing family workers. These categories are less likely to have formal work arrangements or social protection, making workers more susceptible to economic shocks.

Measures the share of male employment that is classified as vulnerable, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Vulnerable employment is the sum of own-account workers (self-employed workers who do not hire employees) and contributing family workers. These categories are less likely to have formal work arrangements or social protection, making workers more susceptible to economic shocks.

Measures the share of total employment that is classified as vulnerable, expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). Vulnerable employment is defined as the sum of own-account workers and contributing family workers. These forms of employment are typically less secure and less likely to have formal work arrangements or social protection, indicating the level of precarity in the labor market.

Measures the share of employed females classified as wage and salaried workers, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. Wage and salaried workers, or employees, are defined as those holding paid employment jobs with contracts that provide a basic remuneration not directly dependent on the business's revenue. This indicator is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), derived from national labor force surveys and other sources. It distinguishes employees from self-employed individuals and contributing family workers, often reflecting the prevalence of formal employment arrangements.

Measures the share of employed males classified as wage and salaried workers, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. Wage and salaried workers, or employees, are defined as those holding paid employment jobs with contracts that provide a basic remuneration not directly dependent on the business's revenue. This indicator is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO), derived from national labor force surveys and other sources. It distinguishes employees from self-employed individuals and contributing family workers, often reflecting the prevalence of formal employment arrangements.

Measures the share of the total employed population classified as wage and salaried workers, expressed as a percentage of total employment. Wage and salaried workers, or employees, hold paid employment jobs with contracts that provide a basic remuneration not directly dependent on the business's revenue. This modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO) is a key indicator of the structure of a labor market, distinguishing formal employees from self-employed individuals and contributing family workers. A higher percentage often corresponds with more advanced economic development.

Represents the share of employed female children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as unpaid family workers, expressed as a percentage. Unpaid family workers are defined as individuals working without direct pay in a market-oriented business operated by a relative in the same household. The data is derived from household surveys, where employment is defined as at least one hour of economic activity during the reference week. This definition includes production of goods for own use but excludes household chores.

Represents the share of employed male children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as unpaid family workers, expressed as a percentage. Unpaid family workers are defined as individuals working without direct pay in a market-oriented business operated by a relative in the same household. The data is derived from household surveys, where employment is defined as at least one hour of economic activity during the reference week. This definition includes production of goods for own use but excludes household chores.

Represents the share of all employed children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as unpaid family workers, expressed as a percentage of all employed children in that age group. Unpaid family workers are defined as individuals working without direct pay in a market-oriented business operated by a relative in the same household. Data is derived from household surveys, with employment defined as at least one hour of economic activity in a reference week, which includes producing goods for own use but excludes household chores.

Measures the proportion of employed females who are contributing family workers, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. A contributing family worker is defined as someone who holds a self-employment job in a market-oriented enterprise operated by a relative living in the same household. These workers are typically unpaid, although they may benefit indirectly from family income. This metric, a modeled ILO estimate, is a key component of 'vulnerable employment' and is used to assess labor market precarity.

Measures the proportion of employed males who are contributing family workers, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. A contributing family worker is defined as someone who holds a self-employment job in a market-oriented enterprise operated by a relative living in the same household. These workers are typically unpaid, although they may benefit indirectly from family income. This metric, a modeled ILO estimate, is a key component of 'vulnerable employment' and is used to assess labor market precarity.

Measures the proportion of the total employed population who are contributing family workers, expressed as a percentage of total employment. A contributing family worker is defined as someone holding a self-employment job in a market-oriented enterprise operated by a relative from the same household. These workers are typically unpaid, benefiting indirectly from family income. This modeled ILO estimate is a primary component of 'vulnerable employment,' often indicating the prevalence of informal or underdeveloped labor markets.

Measures labor productivity as the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per person employed, expressed in constant 2017 international dollars adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). It is calculated by dividing a country's total GDP by its total employment. Using PPP conversion rates eliminates differences in price levels between countries, enabling more accurate comparisons of economic output per unit of labor. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.

Measures the percentage of the total female workforce that is employed in the industry sector. According to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), the industry sector comprises mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water). This modeled ILO estimate reflects the structure of female employment and can indicate shifts in economic development and gender-based sectoral segregation. The classification is by the enterprise's primary activity, not the individual's occupation.

Measures the percentage of the total male workforce that is employed in the industry sector. According to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), the industry sector comprises mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water). This modeled ILO estimate reflects the structure of male employment and can indicate shifts in economic development and labor market dynamics. The classification is by the enterprise's primary activity, not the individual's occupation.

Measures the percentage of a country's total workforce that is employed in the industry sector. The industry sector is defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) and includes mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water). This modeled ILO estimate helps to illustrate a country's economic structure and is a key indicator of industrialization. The classification is based on the economic activity of the enterprise, not the occupation of the individual worker.

Represents the share of economically active female children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the manufacturing sector, expressed as a percentage. An economically active child is defined as one who engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The manufacturing sector is defined according to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). This indicator helps to identify the industrial distribution of child employment, which is a broader concept than child labor.

Represents the share of economically active male children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the manufacturing sector, expressed as a percentage. An economically active child is defined as one who engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The manufacturing sector is defined according to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). This indicator helps to identify the industrial distribution of child employment, which is a broader concept than child labor.

Represents the share of all economically active children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the manufacturing sector, expressed as a percentage. An economically active child is defined as one who engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. The manufacturing sector is defined according to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). This indicator provides insight into the extent to which children are involved in industrial production activities.

Measures the proportion of employed female children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage. Self-employed workers are those whose income is directly dependent on the profits from the goods and services they produce. This category includes employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives. Data are derived from household surveys where employment is defined as at least one hour of economic activity in a reference week, excluding household chores.

Measures the proportion of employed male children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage. Self-employed workers are those whose income is directly dependent on the profits from the goods and services they produce. This category includes employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives. Data are derived from household surveys where employment is defined as at least one hour of economic activity in a reference week, excluding household chores.

Measures the proportion of all employed children, aged 7 to 14, who are classified as self-employed, expressed as a percentage. Self-employed workers are those whose income is directly dependent on profits from the goods and services they produce, a group that includes employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives. The data comes from household surveys, defining employment as at least one hour of economic activity in a reference week and excluding unpaid household chores.

Represents the share of economically active female children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the services sector, expressed as a percentage. The services sector is broadly defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) to include activities like trade, transport, finance, and personal services. An economically active child is one who engaged in at least one hour of economic activity in the reference week. This metric highlights the involvement of young girls in service-related work.

Represents the share of economically active male children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the services sector, expressed as a percentage.
