The services sector is broadly defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) to include activities like trade, transport, finance, and personal services. An economically active child is one who engaged in at least one hour of economic activity in the reference week. This metric highlights the involvement of young boys in service-related work.

Represents the share of all economically active children, aged 7 to 14, who are employed in the services sector, expressed as a percentage. Defined according to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), the services sector includes a wide range of activities such as trade, transport, finance, and community services. The data is based on household surveys where an economically active child is defined as engaging in at least one hour of economic activity per week.

Measures the percentage of the total female workforce that is employed in the services sector. The services sector encompasses a wide range of economic activities, including wholesale and retail trade, transport, finance, real estate, public administration, and personal services, as defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). This modeled ILO estimate is a key indicator of economic structure and can reveal trends in gender-based employment patterns.

Measures the percentage of the total male workforce that is employed in the services sector. This broad sector encompasses activities like wholesale and retail trade, transport, finance, public administration, and personal services, as defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). This modeled ILO estimate is a key indicator of economic structure, often revealing shifts in the male labor market away from agriculture and industry.

Measures the percentage of a country's total workforce that is employed in the services sector. This broad sector, defined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), includes wholesale and retail trade, transport, finance, real estate, and community and personal services. As a modeled ILO estimate, this indicator reflects an economy's structure, with a higher share in services typically associated with higher levels of economic development.

Measures the percentage of the female child population, aged 7 to 14, that is engaged in employment. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), 'children in employment' are those involved in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This definition is broader than 'child labor' and includes market and certain non-market production, but excludes unpaid household chores. It indicates the prevalence of economic activity among young girls.

Measures the percentage of the male child population, aged 7 to 14, that is engaged in employment. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), 'children in employment' are those involved in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This definition is broader than 'child labor' and includes market and certain non-market production, but excludes unpaid household chores. It indicates the prevalence of economic activity among young boys.

Measures the average number of hours worked per week by female children, aged 7 to 14, who are both attending school and engaged in economic activity. This indicator, based on household survey data, focuses specifically on the subset of working children who also maintain their education. It provides insight into the time burden placed on young girls who are balancing the dual responsibilities of school and work.

Represents the share of employed female children, aged 7 to 14, who are also attending school, expressed as a percentage. Employment is defined as engaging in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This indicator helps to understand the extent to which employed girls are able to combine work with education. It is calculated from household survey data and distinguishes this group from children who work but do not attend school.

Measures the average number of hours worked per week by male children, aged 7 to 14, who are both attending school and engaged in economic activity. This indicator, based on household survey data, focuses specifically on the subset of working children who also maintain their education. It provides insight into the time burden placed on young boys who are balancing the dual responsibilities of school and work.

Measures the proportion of employed male children, aged 7-14, who are also attending school, expressed as a percentage. The denominator for this indicator is the total number of employed male children in that age group. A child is considered 'in employment' if they were engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This definition includes various forms of work such as paid labor, unpaid family work, and production of goods for personal use, but excludes unpaid household chores.

Calculates the average weekly working hours for children aged 7-14 who are simultaneously attending school and engaged in employment. The unit is hours per week. A child is considered 'in employment' if they participated in at least one hour of economic activity during the reference week. Economic activity encompasses market production and certain non-market activities, such as producing goods for their own use, but it excludes unpaid household chores. This indicator focuses on the time commitment of children who balance education with work.

Measures the share of employed children, aged 7-14, who are also attending school, expressed as a percentage of all employed children in that age group. A child is defined as 'in employment' if they were engaged in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. Economic activity includes market production, certain non-market production like goods for own use, and various forms of paid or unpaid family work. The definition explicitly excludes unpaid household chores and children who are only seeking work.

Represents the average weekly working hours for female children aged 7-14 who are engaged in employment and do not attend school. The figure is expressed in hours per week. Employment is defined as participation in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This includes market and certain non-market production but excludes unpaid household chores. This indicator specifically quantifies the work intensity for girls who are exclusively part of the workforce and not in education.

Measures the share of employed female children, aged 7-14, who are not attending school, expressed as a percentage of all employed female children in that age group. A child is considered 'in employment' for engaging in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey week. This broad definition of economic activity covers market and certain non-market production but excludes unpaid household services. The indicator highlights the segment of the female child workforce that is completely disengaged from the education system.

Represents the average weekly working hours for male children aged 7-14 who are engaged in employment and do not attend school. The figure is expressed in hours per week. Employment is defined as participation in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. This includes market and certain non-market production but excludes unpaid household chores. This indicator specifically quantifies the work intensity for boys who are exclusively part of the workforce and not in education.

Measures the share of employed male children, aged 7-14, who are not attending school, expressed as a percentage of all employed male children in that age group. A child is considered 'in employment' for engaging in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey week. This broad definition of economic activity covers market and certain non-market production but excludes unpaid household services. The indicator highlights the segment of the male child workforce that is completely disengaged from the education system.

Calculates the average weekly working hours for children aged 7-14 who are involved in employment but do not attend school. This metric is presented in hours per week. The definition of employment requires at least one hour of economic activity in the survey's reference week, covering a range of work types including market production and goods for own use. It specifically excludes unpaid household chores. The indicator focuses on the work burden of children who are not participating in the education system.

Measures the share of employed children, aged 7-14, who are not attending school, expressed as a percentage of all employed children in that age group. A child is considered 'in employment' if they participated in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey week. This definition includes market and certain non-market production but excludes unpaid household services. This indicator quantifies the portion of working children who are outside the education system.

Represents the percentage of all children aged 7-14 who are engaged in employment. A child is considered 'in employment' if they were involved in at least one hour of economic activity during the survey's reference week. 'Economic activity' is a broad term covering market production and certain non-market production, such as producing goods for the household's own use. It is a wider concept than 'child labor' and explicitly excludes activities like unpaid household chores and children only seeking work.

Represents the national estimate of the labor force participation rate for females aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the female population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. This figure is expressed as a percentage of the total female population aged 15-24. Data is based on national sources like labor force surveys, and may differ from the ILO's modeled estimates for the same population group.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for females aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the female population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the female population aged 15-24. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps, which can cause them to differ from purely national estimates.

Represents the national estimate of the labor force participation rate for males aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the male population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. This figure is expressed as a percentage of the total male population aged 15-24. Data is based on national sources like labor force surveys, and may differ from the ILO's modeled estimates for the same population group.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for males aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the male population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the male population aged 15-24. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps, which can cause them to differ from purely national estimates.

Represents the national estimate of the labor force participation rate for the total population aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. This figure is expressed as a percentage of the total population aged 15-24. Data is based on national sources like labor force surveys, and may differ from the ILO's modeled estimates for the same population group.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for the total population aged 15-24. It measures the proportion of the population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the total population aged 15-24. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps, which can cause them to differ from purely national estimates.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for females aged 15-64. It measures the proportion of the female population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the female population aged 15-64. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for males aged 15-64. It measures the proportion of the male population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the male population aged 15-64. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for the total population aged 15-64. It measures the proportion of the population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the total population aged 15-64. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps.

Measures the labor force participation rate for females of working age who have a basic education. It is calculated as the number of females with basic education who are in the labor force (either employed or unemployed), expressed as a percentage of the total working-age female population with the same level of education. Basic education is defined as primary or lower secondary schooling (ISCED 2011 levels 1-2). The indicator reflects the economic activity of women with foundational educational attainment.

Measures the labor force participation rate for males of working age who have a basic education. It is calculated as the number of males with basic education who are in the labor force (either employed or unemployed), expressed as a percentage of the total working-age male population with the same level of education. Basic education is defined as primary or lower secondary schooling (ISCED 2011 levels 1-2). The indicator reflects the economic activity of men with foundational educational attainment.

Measures the labor force participation rate for the total working-age population with a basic education. It is calculated as the number of people with basic education who are in the labor force (either employed or unemployed), expressed as a percentage of the total working-age population with the same level of education. Basic education is defined as primary or lower secondary schooling (ISCED 2011 levels 1-2). The indicator reflects the economic activity of the population with foundational educational attainment.

Represents the national estimate of the labor force participation rate for females aged 15 and older. It measures the proportion of the female population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. This figure is expressed as a percentage of the total female population aged 15 and above. Data is based on national sources like labor force surveys and may differ from the ILO's modeled estimates.

Provides the modeled ILO estimate of the labor force participation rate for females aged 15 and older. It measures the proportion of the female population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the female population aged 15 and older. These ILO estimates are created for international comparability, using national data where available and statistical models to fill in gaps.

Measures the ratio of the female labor force participation rate to the male labor force participation rate for the population aged 15 and older, based on national estimates. It is calculated by dividing the female participation rate by the male participation rate and multiplying by 100. A value of 100 indicates gender parity in economic activity, while values below 100 indicate a lower participation rate for women. The labor force includes all individuals who are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work.

Measures the ratio of the female labor force participation rate to the male labor force participation rate for the population aged 15 and older, based on modeled ILO estimates. It is calculated by dividing the female participation rate by the male rate and multiplying by 100. A value of 100 signifies gender parity. These figures are part of the ILO's harmonized dataset, designed for cross-country comparability, and may differ from ratios calculated from purely national estimates.

Represents the national estimate of the labor force participation rate for males aged 15 and older. It measures the proportion of the male population in this age group that is economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work. This figure is expressed as a percentage of the total male population aged 15 and above. Data is based on national sources like labor force surveys and may differ from the ILO's modeled estimates.

This is a modeled ILO estimate showing the proportion of the male population aged 15 and older that is economically active. It is expressed as a percentage of the total male population in that age group. The labor force, or economically active population, includes all individuals who supply labor for producing goods and services during a specified period, encompassing both the employed and the unemployed. As a modeled estimate, it includes imputed data to ensure cross-country comparability and to calculate regional and global aggregates.

This is a national estimate measuring the proportion of a country's population aged 15 and older that is economically active. The rate is calculated by dividing the total labor force (the sum of employed and unemployed persons) by the total population of the same age group, expressed as a percentage. The labor force includes people who are working or actively seeking work. This indicator is based on official national data, typically from labor force surveys, and may differ from modeled international estimates due to variations in methodology.

This modeled ILO estimate represents the proportion of the total population aged 15 and older that is economically active. It is calculated by dividing the total labor force by the corresponding population and is expressed as a percentage. The labor force includes all people who supply labor for economic production, covering both employed and unemployed individuals. The use of modeled estimates by the ILO allows for standardized comparisons across countries by harmonizing definitions and filling data gaps.

Measures the labor force participation rate among females of working age who have completed an intermediate level of education. It is expressed as a percentage of the female working-age population with the same educational attainment. 'Intermediate education' corresponds to upper secondary or post-secondary non-tertiary education as defined by the ISCED 2011 classification. The indicator shows the extent to which this specific demographic group is economically active, either by being employed or actively seeking employment.

Measures the labor force participation rate among males of working age who have completed an intermediate level of education. It is expressed as a percentage of the male working-age population with the same educational attainment. 'Intermediate education' corresponds to upper secondary or post-secondary non-tertiary education as defined by the ISCED 2011 classification. The indicator reflects the economic activity of this specific demographic group, including both employed and unemployed individuals.

Measures the labor force participation rate for the total working-age population with an intermediate level of education. This rate is calculated as the percentage of the labor force with intermediate education relative to the entire working-age population with that same level of education. According to the ISCED 2011 standard, 'intermediate education' includes upper secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education. It indicates the degree of economic engagement among individuals with this specific educational background.

Represents the share of employed females who work part-time, expressed as a percentage of total female employment. Part-time employment is commonly defined as working less than 35 actual hours per week. This indicator provides insight into the nature of female employment and the prevalence of flexible or non-standard work arrangements. It is calculated based on data from labor force surveys, which collect information on hours worked.

Represents the share of employed males who work part-time, expressed as a percentage of total male employment. Part-time work is generally defined based on a threshold of less than 35 actual weekly hours worked. This metric is used to analyze patterns in male employment, such as the prevalence of non-standard work arrangements. The data is primarily sourced from national labor force surveys.

Measures the proportion of the total employed population that works part-time, expressed as a percentage of total employment. The definition of part-time is typically based on a threshold of less than 35 actual hours worked per week, although this can vary by country. This indicator reflects the overall prevalence of part-time work in an economy, which can be influenced by economic conditions, labor market regulations, and social preferences.

Measures the share of the total labor force that is female, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of females in the labor force by the total labor force (males and females combined). The labor force comprises all people aged 15 and older who are either employed or unemployed but actively seeking work. This indicator reflects the gender composition of the economically active population and is a key measure of women's participation in the economy.

Represents the total number of people in the labor force, measured as an absolute count of persons. The labor force includes all individuals aged 15 and older who are economically active, meaning they are either employed or unemployed and actively seeking work during a specified period. This is a modeled ILO estimate, which harmonizes national data and imputes missing values to provide a comprehensive count for cross-country analysis. Students, unpaid family workers, and sometimes armed forces may be excluded.

This national estimate measures the unemployment rate for young females, defined as the percentage of the female labor force aged 15-24 that is unemployed. Unemployed individuals are those who are without a job, currently available for work, and have actively sought employment in a recent period. The denominator is the youth female labor force (employed plus unemployed), not the total youth female population. As a national estimate, it is based on country-reported data from sources like labor force surveys.

This modeled ILO estimate measures the unemployment rate for young females, representing the share of the female labor force aged 15-24 that is without work but available for and seeking employment. It is expressed as a percentage of the youth female labor force (the sum of employed and unemployed). The modeled estimate is designed for international comparability, using a standardized methodology and imputing data for countries where it is unavailable, which may differ from national estimates.

This national estimate measures the unemployment rate for young males, calculated as the percentage of the male labor force aged 15-24 that is unemployed. According to standard definitions, the unemployed are those without work, available for work, and actively seeking it. The rate is based on the youth male labor force (both employed and unemployed), not the total youth male population. Data is sourced from official national statistics, typically labor force surveys.

This modeled ILO estimate measures the unemployment rate for young males, defined as the percentage of the male labor force aged 15-24 that is unemployed but available for and seeking work. The rate is calculated using the youth male labor force (employed plus unemployed) as the denominator. The ILO's modeling process harmonizes data and fills gaps to produce internationally comparable estimates for analyzing global and regional trends in youth unemployment.

This national estimate represents the total youth unemployment rate, measuring the percentage of the total labor force aged 15-24 that is unemployed. Unemployed youth are defined as those without a job, available to work, and actively seeking one. The denominator for this rate is the total youth labor force, which includes both employed and unemployed young people. The data is derived from official national sources and reflects country-specific definitions and methodologies.

This modeled ILO estimate measures the total youth unemployment rate, which is the share of the labor force aged 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment. It is expressed as a percentage of the total youth labor force (both male and female). These estimates are produced by the ILO to provide internationally comparable data on youth unemployment, using a consistent methodology and imputing values for countries with missing data.

Measures the unemployment rate specifically for females in the labor force who have an advanced level of education. It is expressed as a percentage of the female labor force with this educational attainment. 'Advanced education' is defined by the ISCED 2011 classification and includes tertiary levels such as bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees. The indicator helps analyze labor market outcomes for highly educated women and potential skills mismatches.

Measures the unemployment rate for males in the labor force with an advanced level of education. The rate is calculated as the number of unemployed males with advanced education divided by the total male labor force with the same educational level, expressed as a percentage. 'Advanced education' includes all tertiary levels (e.g., bachelor's, master's, doctoral degrees) according to the ISCED 2011 standard. It provides insight into the employment challenges faced by highly skilled men.

Measures the unemployment rate for the total labor force with an advanced level of education. It is calculated as the percentage of individuals with advanced education in the labor force who are unemployed. 'Advanced education' comprises tertiary levels, including short-cycle tertiary, bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees, as per the ISCED 2011 classification. This indicator is useful for assessing the labor market integration of the most highly educated segment of the workforce.

Measures the unemployment rate among females in the labor force who have a basic level of education. It is expressed as a percentage of the female labor force with the same educational background. 'Basic education' is defined by the ISCED 2011 classification to include primary and lower secondary education. This indicator highlights the employment vulnerabilities of women with lower levels of formal schooling.

Measures the unemployment rate among males in the labor force with a basic level of education. This rate is the percentage of unemployed males with basic education out of the total male labor force with that same educational level. According to the ISCED 2011 standard, 'basic education' comprises primary and lower secondary schooling. The indicator helps to understand the labor market challenges for men with limited formal education.

Measures the unemployment rate for the total labor force with a basic level of education. It is calculated as the percentage of the labor force with basic education that is unemployed. 'Basic education' is defined under the ISCED 2011 classification and includes primary and lower secondary levels. This indicator provides a measure of labor market underutilization among workers with lower educational attainment.

Measures the unemployment rate among females in the labor force who have an intermediate level of education. It is expressed as a percentage of the female labor force with the same educational attainment. 'Intermediate education' is defined by the ISCED 2011 classification as upper secondary or post-secondary non-tertiary education. The indicator shows unemployment patterns for women who have completed secondary schooling or equivalent vocational training.

Measures the unemployment rate for males in the labor force with an intermediate level of education. The rate is the percentage of unemployed males with intermediate education relative to the total male labor force with that same educational level. 'Intermediate education,' per the ISCED 2011 standard, includes upper secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education. It reflects employment outcomes for men with mid-level skills and qualifications.

Measures the unemployment rate for the total labor force with an intermediate level of education. It is calculated as the percentage of the labor force with intermediate education that is unemployed. 'Intermediate education' covers upper secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education according to the ISCED 2011 classification. This indicator helps assess labor market conditions for the segment of the workforce with mid-level educational qualifications.

This modeled ILO estimate measures the share of young females who are not in employment, education, or training (NEET). It is expressed as a percentage of the total female population aged 15-24. The NEET category includes youth who are either unemployed or economically inactive and are not enrolled in formal or non-formal education or training programs. As a modeled estimate, it provides internationally comparable data on the disengagement of young women from both the labor market and skill development.

Measures the share of young females who are not in employment, education, or training (NEET), based on national data sources. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the total female population aged 15-24. This indicator captures young women who are disengaged from both the workforce and educational systems, including those who are unemployed and not in training, as well as those who are economically inactive. It provides a broad measure of youth vulnerability and social exclusion.

This modeled ILO estimate measures the share of young males who are not in employment, education, or training (NEET). It is calculated as a percentage of the total male population aged 15-24. The NEET group comprises young men who are either unemployed or economically inactive, and who are not participating in any formal or non-formal education or training. This standardized measure allows for cross-country comparison of male youth disengagement.

Measures the share of young males who are not in employment, education, or training (NEET), based on national data. The rate is expressed as a percentage of the total male population aged 15-24. It encompasses young men who are neither gaining work experience nor investing in their skills through education or training, thus capturing a broader group than unemployment alone. This indicator is a key measure of the challenges young men face in transitioning to adulthood.

Measures the share of the male youth population, ages 15 to 24, that is not in education, employment, or training (NEET), expressed as a percentage. This is a modeled estimate from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The NEET category includes young men who are either unemployed or economically inactive and are not engaged in formal education or vocational training. Education covers formal and non-formal settings but excludes informal learning, while training is defined as school-based vocational or technical programs, excluding employer-based training.

Measures the share of the total youth population, ages 15 to 24, that is not in education, employment, or training (NEET), expressed as a percentage. The NEET category includes young people who are either unemployed or economically inactive and are not engaged in formal education or vocational training. Education covers formal and non-formal settings but excludes informal learning, while training is defined as school-based vocational or technical programs, excluding employer-based training. The indicator highlights the segment of youth potentially at risk of social and labor market exclusion.

Represents the share of the female labor force that is unemployed but available for and seeking work, based on national estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total female labor force. The definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work during a reference period, were available for work, and had taken specific steps to find employment. This indicator relies on national definitions which may differ across countries and generally excludes discouraged workers who are not actively seeking employment.

Represents the share of the female labor force that is unemployed, based on modeled International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total female labor force. The ILO's standardized definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work, currently available for work, and actively seeking it. The modeled estimates are created to provide a comparable dataset across countries, filling data gaps through statistical imputation, and should be used with caution for direct country comparisons.

Represents the share of the male labor force that is unemployed but available for and seeking work, based on national estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total male labor force. The definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work during a reference period, were available for work, and had taken specific steps to find employment. This indicator relies on national definitions which may differ across countries and generally excludes discouraged workers who are not actively seeking employment.

Represents the share of the male labor force that is unemployed, based on modeled International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total male labor force. The ILO's standardized definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work, currently available for work, and actively seeking it. The modeled estimates are created to provide a comparable dataset across countries, filling data gaps through statistical imputation, and should be used with caution for direct country comparisons.

Represents the share of the total labor force (both sexes) that is unemployed but available for and seeking work, based on national estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total labor force. The definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work during a reference period, were available for work, and had taken specific steps to find employment. This indicator relies on national definitions which may differ across countries and generally excludes discouraged workers who are not actively seeking employment.

Represents the share of the total labor force (both sexes) that is unemployed, based on modeled International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates. It is expressed as a percentage of the total labor force. The ILO's standardized definition of unemployment includes individuals of working age who were without work, currently available for work, and actively seeking it. The modeled estimates are created to provide a comparable dataset across countries, filling data gaps through statistical imputation, and should be used with caution for direct country comparisons.

Measures the proportion of employed female children, ages 7 to 14, who work as wage workers, expressed as a percentage. Wage workers are defined as those with an explicit or implicit contract for basic remuneration that is not directly dependent on the revenue of their employer. 'Children in employment' refers to engagement in any economic activity for at least one hour during a reference period. This definition is broader than child labor and excludes unpaid household chores. Data is typically sourced from household surveys.

Measures the proportion of employed male children, ages 7 to 14, who work as wage workers, expressed as a percentage. Wage workers are defined as those with an explicit or implicit contract for basic remuneration that is not directly dependent on the revenue of their employer. 'Children in employment' refers to engagement in any economic activity for at least one hour during a reference period. This definition is broader than child labor and excludes unpaid household chores. Data is typically sourced from household surveys.

Measures the proportion of employed children, ages 7 to 14, who work as wage workers, expressed as a percentage of all employed children in that age group. Wage workers are defined as those with an explicit or implicit contract for basic remuneration that is not directly dependent on the revenue of their employer. 'Children in employment' refers to engagement in any economic activity for at least one hour during a reference period. This definition is broader than child labor and excludes unpaid household chores.

Represents the total number of individuals who have sought international protection in a specific country or territory and are awaiting a final decision on their asylum claim. This count, provided by the UNHCR, includes people at all stages of the asylum process, from initial application to appeal. The data is compiled from administrative records of national asylum authorities and reflects the pending caseload of protection claims within a host country.

Represents the total number of individuals from a specific country or territory of origin who have sought international protection and are awaiting a final decision on their asylum claim in another country. This count, provided by the UNHCR, includes people at all stages of the asylum process, from initial application to appeal. The data is compiled from administrative records of national asylum authorities and reflects the number of people who have fled a particular country seeking protection.

Measures the total number of forcibly displaced people globally. This is a comprehensive figure calculated as the sum of five distinct groups: refugees under UNHCR mandate, refugees under UNRWA mandate for Palestine refugees, asylum-seekers, internally displaced people (IDPs), and other people in need of international protection. The data, compiled by UNHCR, aims to account for overlaps between categories to avoid double-counting. The indicator provides a broad overview of the scale of forced displacement due to conflict, violence, or human rights violations.

Represents the total number of internally displaced persons (IDPs) within a country. IDPs are defined as individuals or groups who have been forced to flee their homes as a result of armed conflict, generalized violence, or human rights violations, but who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border. Data is compiled by UNHCR and the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) from various sources including government records, censuses, surveys, and humanitarian operational data.

Measures the net total of migrants during a period, calculated as the number of immigrants entering a country minus the number of emigrants leaving that country. The figure, expressed as a total number, includes both citizens and non-citizens. A positive value indicates a net inflow of people, while a negative value signifies a net outflow. When direct migration data is unavailable, it is often estimated as the residual of total population change minus natural increase (births minus deaths).

Represents the total number of people hosted by a specific country who are in need of international protection but do not fall under the legal categories of refugee or asylum-seeker. This UNHCR category includes individuals forcibly displaced across international borders who require protection from forced return and access to essential services. Data is primarily sourced from administrative records and humanitarian operations, capturing vulnerable populations beyond traditional classifications.

Represents the total number of people from a specific country of origin who are in need of international protection but do not fall under the legal categories of refugee or asylum-seeker. This UNHCR category includes individuals forcibly displaced across international borders who require protection from forced return and access to essential services. Data is primarily sourced from administrative records and humanitarian operations, capturing vulnerable populations who have fled their home country.

Measures the total number of refugees and people in refugee-like situations falling under the mandate of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), hosted by a specific country or territory of asylum. This count includes individuals recognized under international conventions (like the 1951 Refugee Convention), those granted complementary or temporary protection, and groups who are outside their country of origin and face similar protection risks. It explicitly excludes Palestine refugees who are registered under the UNRWA mandate.

Measures the total number of refugees and people in refugee-like situations from a specific country of origin who fall under the mandate of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). This count includes individuals recognized under international conventions (like the 1951 Refugee Convention), those granted complementary or temporary protection, and groups who are outside their country of origin and face similar protection risks. It explicitly excludes Palestine refugees who are registered under the UNRWA mandate.

Represents the total number of Palestine refugees registered with the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), located in a specific country or territory of asylum. This distinct group is defined as persons whose normal residence was Palestine between June 1946 and May 1948, who lost both home and livelihood due to the 1948 conflict, and their descendants. Data is based on UNRWA's registration records and is separate from the refugee populations under UNHCR's mandate.

Represents the total number of Palestine refugees registered with the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), by their country or territory of origin. This group is defined as persons whose normal residence was Palestine between June 1946 and May 1948, who lost both home and livelihood due to the 1948 conflict, and their descendants. Data is based on UNRWA's registration records and is separate from the refugee populations under UNHCR's mandate.

Represents the total number of international migrants residing in a country, referred to as the migrant stock. The primary definition of an international migrant is a person born in a country other than the one in which they live (foreign-born). If foreign-born data is unavailable, the number of foreign citizens is used as an estimate. This stock figure, which includes refugees, is typically derived from population censuses. Changes in international borders can create statistical discontinuities.

Measures the share of international migrants within a country's total population, expressed as a percentage. The international migrant stock is the number of people born in a country other than that in which they live. When data on the foreign-born population is unavailable, data on the foreign-citizen population is used instead. This indicator, which includes refugees, provides a measure of the relative size of the immigrant community in a country.

Measures the percentage of the population whose regular food consumption is insufficient to provide the dietary energy levels required for an active and healthy life. This Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) indicator is based on a calculation considering average food availability, inequality in food access, and minimum caloric requirements. It specifically reflects chronic energy deprivation, or hunger. A reported value of 2.5% can signify a prevalence at or below that level.

Represents the percentage of the population living in households that have experienced moderate or severe food insecurity. This measure is based on the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES), a survey-based tool that captures a household's inability to access adequate food due to a lack of money or other resources. Moderate food insecurity involves reduced diet quality and uncertainty about obtaining food, while severe insecurity involves reducing food quantity and skipping meals.

Measures the percentage of households that use salt that contains iodine, a key intervention to prevent iodine deficiency disorders. The data is typically collected through household surveys where a sample of the salt used for cooking is tested for the presence of iodine (a positive test is greater than 0 parts per million). This indicator tracks the reach of national salt iodization programs, which are critical for preventing cognitive impairments and other health issues.

Represents the percentage of the population that has experienced severe food insecurity. This measure is based on the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES) and identifies households where at least one adult has likely been forced to reduce food quantity, skip meals, or even go a full day without eating due to a lack of money or other resources. It signifies a critical lack of access to food and is a direct measure of hunger.

Measures the percentage of children between 6 and 59 months of age who received two high-dose vitamin A supplements within a calendar year. Vitamin A supplementation is a crucial public health intervention to prevent deficiency, which is a leading cause of preventable childhood blindness and increases the risk of death from common illnesses. The coverage rate reflects the effectiveness of national health programs in reaching this vulnerable age group.

Represents the number of births occurring per 1,000 women within the adolescent age group of 15 to 19. This rate is calculated annually based on live birth data from civil registration systems, or estimated from population censuses and sample surveys when registration data is incomplete. The indicator is a key measure of teenage pregnancy and is relevant for assessing reproductive health, education, and economic outcomes for young women.

Measures the probability of a 15-year-old female dying before reaching age 60, assuming she is subject to the age-specific mortality rates of a specified year. It is expressed as a rate per 1,000 female adults. This indicator is calculated from period life tables, which provide a snapshot of a population's mortality patterns. The primary data sources are vital registration systems, censuses, and surveys. It serves as a key indicator of a country's health status and socioeconomic development, particularly for identifying vulnerable populations.

Measures the probability of a 15-year-old male dying before reaching age 60, based on the age-specific mortality rates for a given year. The rate is expressed per 1,000 male adults. The calculation is derived from male period life tables, which reflect the mortality patterns across all age groups at a specific point in time. Data is typically sourced from vital registration systems, censuses, or sample surveys. This metric is a significant indicator of health status and is used for socioeconomic comparisons across countries.

Represents the number of live births occurring during a year for every 1,000 people in the population, estimated at midyear. It is a 'crude' measure because it does not take into account the age or sex structure of the population. The indicator is calculated by dividing the total number of births in a year by the midyear population. When combined with the crude death rate, it can be used to determine the rate of natural population increase, excluding migration. Data is primarily sourced from vital registration systems, censuses, and surveys.

Indicates the number of deaths occurring during a year per 1,000 people, based on the midyear population estimate. This is a 'crude' rate as it does not account for the age distribution of the population, which can affect comparisons between countries. For example, a country with a large elderly population may have a higher crude death rate even with high life expectancy. Subtracting this rate from the crude birth rate yields the rate of natural population increase, exclusive of migration.

Measures the percentage of married or in-union women between the ages of 15 and 49 who are currently using, or whose partners are using, at least one modern method of contraception. Modern methods include female and male sterilization, oral hormonal pills, IUDs, male condoms, injectables, implants, and emergency contraception. The data is primarily collected through nationally representative household surveys. This indicator is crucial for assessing access to family planning services and monitoring progress in reproductive health.

Represents the percentage of married or in-union women aged 15-49 who are currently using, or whose partners are using, any method of contraception, whether modern or traditional. Modern methods include sterilization, pills, and condoms, while traditional methods include rhythm (periodic abstinence) and withdrawal. Data is primarily sourced from household surveys like the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS). The indicator reflects the extent of family planning practices within a population.

Measures the number of female infants who die before reaching one year of age, expressed per 1,000 female live births in a specific year. This indicator is a key measure of child health and overall socioeconomic development. Data is often estimated by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME), which uses statistical models to ensure consistency across different sources, including vital registration systems and household surveys.

Represents the number of infants dying before reaching their first birthday, expressed per 1,000 live births in a given year. This rate is a widely used indicator of a country's health status, reflecting factors such as maternal health, quality of medical care, and public health conditions. The UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) produces harmonized estimates using data from vital registration systems, censuses, and surveys to ensure cross-country comparability.

Measures the number of male infants who die before reaching one year of age, expressed per 1,000 male live births in a specific year. As a gender-disaggregated measure of child health, it helps identify potential disparities and informs public health policies. The UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME) harmonizes data from various national sources, including vital statistics and surveys, to produce comparable estimates.

Indicates the average number of years a newborn female would be expected to live if the mortality patterns at the time of her birth were to remain constant throughout her life. Measured in years, this indicator provides a summary of the mortality conditions across all age groups for females in a given year. It is calculated using period life tables based on age-specific death rates and is a key indicator of a population's overall health and well-being.

Represents the average number of years a newborn infant would live if the prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life. Measured in years, it is a comprehensive indicator of a country's overall health status. The calculation is based on period life tables, which use age-specific death rates for a given year to summarize the mortality level of a population.

Indicates the average number of years a newborn male would be expected to live if the mortality patterns at the time of his birth were to remain constant throughout his life. Measured in years, this indicator summarizes the mortality conditions for males across all age groups in a specific year. It is derived from period life tables using age-specific death rates and serves as a fundamental measure of population health.

Represents the hypothetical number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with the age-specific fertility rates of a specified year. It is expressed as the average number of births per woman. This indicator provides a snapshot of fertility behavior in a single year and is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates. It's a key demographic indicator for understanding population dynamics.

Measures the percentage of a cohort of newborn females that would be expected to survive to age 65, if subject to the age-specific mortality rates prevailing in a given year. This indicator is calculated from period life tables and reflects the cumulative impact of mortality from birth up to age 65. It serves as an important summary measure of premature mortality and the overall health status of a female population.

Measures the percentage of a cohort of newborn males that would be expected to survive to age 65, based on the age-specific mortality rates of a specified year. Calculated from period life tables, this metric provides insight into premature mortality and the overall health of a male population by summarizing death rates across all ages up to 65.

Estimates the total fertility rate that would result if all unwanted births were avoided, expressed as the average number of births per woman. This indicator is calculated using data from household surveys, primarily the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS). A birth is considered wanted if the mother's number of living children at the time of conception was less than her stated ideal number of children. The metric helps quantify the potential impact of meeting the demand for family planning.

Measures the share of households that are headed by females, expressed as a percentage of all households. A household is typically defined as a person or group of people who live together and share common living arrangements, acknowledging one person as the head. This indicator is important for understanding household composition and poverty dynamics, though comparability can be limited by varying definitions of 'household head' and potential gender biases in reporting.

Represents the percentage of women currently aged 20-24 who were first married or entered into an informal union before the age of 15. This is a key indicator for monitoring child marriage (SDG 5.3.1). It is measured retrospectively for the 20-24 age cohort to provide a current and reliable snapshot of the practice. The indicator includes both formal marriages and informal unions where couples live together as if married.

Represents the percentage of women currently aged 20-24 who were first married or entered into an informal union before reaching the age of 18. This is the primary indicator for Sustainable Development Goal 5.3.1, aimed at eliminating child marriage. The data is collected retrospectively from women aged 20-24 to capture a recent and stable estimate of the practice. It encompasses both formal, legally recognized marriages and informal cohabiting unions.

Measures the percentage of adolescent women between the ages of 15 and 19 who have already had a child or are currently pregnant. This indicator is a key measure of adolescent reproductive health and is compiled from data collected in household surveys, such as the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS). Early childbearing can have significant health, social, and economic consequences for young mothers and their children.

Represents the number of females between the ages of 0 and 4, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. These are midyear estimates based on data from the UN's World Population Prospects. This indicator helps in understanding the age structure of the female population, which is crucial for planning services related to child health, early education, and maternal care.

Represents the number of males between the ages of 0 and 4, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. The data are midyear estimates derived from the UN's World Population Prospects. This metric is a fundamental component of demographic analysis, useful for assessing future population trends and planning for services such as healthcare and education.

Indicates the total number of females between the ages of 0 and 14 in a given year. The figure is a midyear estimate based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all residents regardless of their legal status or citizenship. This data is essential for calculating dependency ratios and for planning social services, education, and healthcare tailored to the needs of the young female population.

Measures the share of the female population that is between the ages of 0 and 14, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. Based on midyear estimates, this indicator reflects the proportion of young dependents and is a key component in calculating age dependency ratios. It is crucial for understanding population structure and planning for future needs in education, health, and social services.

Represents the total number of males between the ages of 0 and 14. These are midyear estimates based on the de facto population, counting all residents irrespective of legal status. This demographic data is fundamental for national planning, particularly for infrastructure and services such as education and healthcare, and is a key input for calculating age dependency ratios.

Measures the percentage of the male population that is between the ages of 0 and 14, relative to the total male population. This midyear estimate helps illustrate the age structure and the burden of youth dependency within the male population. It is a critical indicator for policymakers analyzing demographic trends and planning for future social and economic development.

Indicates the total number of people between the ages of 0 and 14, including both males and females. The data are midyear estimates based on the de facto definition of population, counting all residents regardless of legal status. This figure is a primary component for calculating the age dependency ratio and is essential for governments in planning for education, healthcare, and other services for children and adolescents.

Measures the percentage of a country's total population that is between the ages of 0 and 14. This indicator, based on midyear estimates, reflects the proportion of the population in the youth dependency category. It is a crucial demographic metric for assessing the age structure of a population, which influences resource allocation for education, healthcare, and social security systems.

Represents the number of females between the ages of 5 and 9, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. These are midyear estimates based on UN demographic data. This indicator helps to detail the age composition of the population, which is vital for planning primary education and child health services.

Represents the number of males between the ages of 5 and 9, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. These midyear estimates are derived from UN population data and are important for analyzing the demographic structure. This information is particularly relevant for planning educational capacity and healthcare services for school-aged children.

Measures the percentage of a country's total female population that is in the 10-14 age group. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of females aged 10 to 14 by the total female population and multiplying by 100. The data is based on midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which are derived from demographic models considering fertility, mortality, and migration. Understanding this age-sex cohort is crucial for planning services related to education, health, and social development.

Measures the percentage of a country's total male population that is in the 10-14 age group. It is calculated by dividing the number of males aged 10 to 14 by the total male population and multiplying by 100. The data originates from midyear population estimates provided by the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which are based on demographic components like fertility, mortality, and migration. This metric is essential for analyzing population structure and planning for future infrastructure and service needs.

Represents the proportion of a country's total female population that falls within the 15-19 age bracket, expressed as a percentage. The calculation involves dividing the number of females in this age group by the total female population. Data is sourced from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, relying on midyear estimates that account for demographic trends. This indicator is important for understanding the demographic profile of young women, which informs policies on higher education, employment, and reproductive health.

Represents the proportion of a country's total male population that falls within the 15-19 age bracket, expressed as a percentage. The calculation involves dividing the number of males in this age group by the total male population. Data is sourced from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, relying on midyear estimates that account for demographic trends. This indicator is key for assessing the size of the young male cohort entering higher education, the workforce, or military service.

Measures the total number of females in the working-age population, defined as those between the ages of 15 and 64. The data is based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all residents of a country, regardless of their legal status or citizenship. These figures are midyear estimates derived from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, combined with World Bank staff estimates. This absolute number is crucial for assessing the female labor supply and for calculating metrics like the age dependency ratio.

Measures the share of the total female population that is considered to be of working age (15-64 years), expressed as a percentage. Population estimates are based on the de facto definition, counting all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. The indicator is calculated using midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. It provides insight into the proportion of females who are potential contributors to the labor force, which is a key factor in economic and social development.

Measures the total number of males in the working-age population, defined as those between the ages of 15 and 64. The data is based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all residents of a country, regardless of their legal status or citizenship. These figures represent midyear estimates derived from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects and World Bank staff estimates. This indicator is a fundamental component for analyzing the male labor force and calculating demographic dependency ratios.

Measures the share of the total male population that is considered to be of working age (15-64 years), expressed as a percentage. Population figures are based on the de facto definition, which includes all residents regardless of their legal status. The indicator is calculated from midyear population estimates sourced from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. It reflects the proportion of the male population that is potentially economically active, a critical factor for economic analysis and planning.

Represents the total number of people in the working-age population, defined as those between the ages of 15 and 64. The figures are based on the de facto definition of population, counting all residents irrespective of legal status or citizenship. These are midyear estimates based on data from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects and World Bank staff estimates. This absolute measure of the working-age population is essential for calculating the age dependency ratio and assessing a country's potential labor force.

Measures the percentage of a country's total population that is of working age, typically defined as ages 15 to 64. The population data adheres to the de facto definition, which includes all residents regardless of legal status. This indicator is calculated from midyear estimates provided by the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. A higher percentage generally indicates a larger potential workforce relative to the dependent population (children and elderly), which can be a driver of economic growth.

Measures the share of a country's total female population that falls within the 20-24 age group, expressed as a percentage. The value is calculated by dividing the number of females aged 20 to 24 by the total female population. Data is derived from midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which are based on demographic models accounting for fertility, mortality, and migration. This metric helps in understanding the specific age structure of the young adult female population.

Measures the share of a country's total male population that falls within the 20-24 age group, expressed as a percentage. The value is calculated by dividing the number of males aged 20 to 24 by the total male population. Data is derived from midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which are based on demographic models accounting for fertility, mortality, and migration. This metric helps in understanding the specific age structure of the young adult male population.

Measures the percentage of a country's total female population that is in the 25-29 age bracket. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of females aged 25 to 29 by the total female population. The data is based on midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which considers key demographic components like fertility, mortality, and migration. It provides insight into the demographic cohort often associated with family formation and career establishment.

Measures the percentage of a country's total male population that is in the 25-29 age bracket. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of males aged 25 to 29 by the total male population. The data is based on midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, which considers key demographic components like fertility, mortality, and migration. It offers a view of the demographic cohort crucial for labor market analysis and social planning.

Represents the proportion of a country's total female population within the 30-34 age group, expressed as a percentage. The calculation involves dividing the female population aged 30-34 by the total female population. Data is sourced from midyear estimates provided by the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This indicator is useful for analyzing demographic trends related to prime working years and fertility patterns for women in this age cohort.

Represents the proportion of a country's total male population within the 30-34 age group, expressed as a percentage. The calculation involves dividing the male population aged 30-34 by the total male population. Data is sourced from midyear estimates provided by the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This metric helps in understanding the population structure of men in their prime working years, which is relevant for economic and social policy.

Measures the share of the total female population that is between 35 and 39 years old, shown as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of females in this five-year age cohort by the total female population. The underlying data consists of midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This indicator helps track the demographic distribution of women in a key phase of their careers and family life.

Measures the share of the total male population that is between 35 and 39 years old, shown as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of males in this five-year age cohort by the total male population. The underlying data consists of midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This demographic indicator is important for analyzing the labor force and planning for health and social services.

Indicates the percentage of the total female population that is aged 40 to 44. This proportion is calculated by dividing the number of females in this age group by the entire female population. The figures are based on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. The indicator is valuable for understanding the demographic weight of middle-aged women, informing policies on employment, health, and social security.

Indicates the percentage of the total male population that is aged 40 to 44. This proportion is calculated by dividing the number of males in this age group by the entire male population. The figures are based on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. The indicator provides insight into the size of the middle-aged male cohort, which is significant for economic productivity and health planning.

Represents the share of a country's total female population that is in the 45-49 age group, expressed as a percentage. It is derived by dividing the number of females aged 45 to 49 by the total female population. The data is based on midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This demographic measure is important for analyzing the workforce, health trends, and planning for retirement systems.

Represents the share of a country's total male population that is in the 45-49 age group, expressed as a percentage. It is derived by dividing the number of males aged 45 to 49 by the total male population. The data is based on midyear population estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This indicator helps in understanding the age structure of the experienced workforce and planning for future social security needs.

Measures the percentage of the total female population that is aged 50 to 54. This is calculated by dividing the number of females in this age cohort by the total female population. The source of the data is the midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This indicator is crucial for analyzing the demographics of older workers, planning for healthcare needs, and understanding retirement trends.

Measures the percentage of the total male population that is aged 50 to 54. This is calculated by dividing the number of males in this age cohort by the total male population. The source of the data is the midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. It provides insight into the population approaching retirement age, which is vital for labor market and pension system analysis.

Indicates the proportion of the total female population aged 55 to 59, expressed as a percentage. The value is calculated by dividing the female population in this age range by the total female population. These figures are midyear estimates based on the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This demographic indicator is key for understanding the population segment transitioning towards retirement and for planning related health and social services.

Indicates the proportion of the total male population aged 55 to 59, expressed as a percentage. The value is calculated by dividing the male population in this age range by the total male population. These figures are midyear estimates based on the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. The indicator is essential for analyzing labor force dynamics near retirement age and for social security planning.

Measures the share of the total female population that falls within the 60-64 age bracket, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of females in this age group by the total female population. The data is based on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This metric is important for assessing the size of the senior population at the cusp of traditional retirement age, informing policy on pensions and healthcare.

Measures the share of the total male population that falls within the 60-64 age bracket, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the number of males in this age group by the total male population. The data is based on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This indicator helps policymakers and analysts understand the demographics of the older workforce and plan for retirement systems.

Represents the percentage of a country's total female population that is aged 65 to 69. This is calculated by dividing the number of females in this cohort by the total female population. The indicator relies on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. It is a key metric for understanding population aging and for planning social security, pension, and healthcare services for the elderly.

Represents the percentage of a country's total male population that is aged 65 to 69. This is calculated by dividing the number of males in this cohort by the total male population. The indicator relies on midyear estimates from the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects. This data is vital for assessing the dependency ratio, population aging, and the sustainability of social support systems for the elderly.

Measures the total number of females aged 65 years and older within a country. The data represents midyear estimates and is based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all residents regardless of their legal status or citizenship. This indicator provides an absolute count of the elderly female population, which is crucial for understanding demographic trends and planning for social services.

Represents the share of the female population that is 65 years of age or older, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. The calculation is based on midyear population estimates using the de facto definition, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. This indicator is key for analyzing the age structure of the female population and the potential social and economic implications of an aging society.

Measures the total number of males aged 65 years and older within a country. The data represents midyear estimates and is based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all residents regardless of their legal status or citizenship. This indicator provides an absolute count of the elderly male population, essential for demographic analysis and policy planning.

Represents the share of the male population that is 65 years of age or older, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. The calculation is based on midyear population estimates using the de facto definition, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. This metric helps in understanding the aging dynamics within the male population of a country.

Measures the total population, including both males and females, aged 65 years and older. The figure is a midyear estimate based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. This indicator provides the absolute size of the elderly population, a key variable for assessing the potential burden on healthcare and pension systems.

Represents the share of the total population that is 65 years of age or older, expressed as a percentage. This metric is calculated from midyear population estimates based on the de facto definition, which includes all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. It is a fundamental indicator of population aging and is used in calculating the age dependency ratio.

Measures the share of the female population within the 70 to 74 age group, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. The values are midyear estimates derived from demographic models. This indicator provides a detailed view of the age structure within the older female population, which is useful for targeted policy-making and service planning.

Measures the share of the male population within the 70 to 74 age group, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. These figures are midyear estimates based on demographic models. This indicator offers granular insight into the age distribution of the older male population, contributing to a more detailed demographic analysis.

Measures the share of the female population within the 75 to 79 age group, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. The values are midyear estimates derived from demographic models. This indicator helps in understanding the demographic composition of the very old female population, which is relevant for health and social care planning.
