Measures the share of the male population within the 75 to 79 age group, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. These figures are midyear estimates based on demographic models. The indicator provides a detailed breakdown of the older male age structure, which is important for demographic projections and policy formulation.

Measures the share of the female population aged 80 years and over, expressed as a percentage of the total female population. Based on midyear estimates, this indicator highlights the proportion of the oldest-old segment among females, a demographic group with specific health and social support needs.

Measures the share of the male population aged 80 years and over, expressed as a percentage of the total male population. Based on midyear estimates, this indicator tracks the size of the oldest-old segment among males, providing insight into longevity and the demands on long-term care systems.

Measures the sex ratio at birth, defined as the number of male births for every female birth in a given year. It is calculated by dividing the total number of male births by the total number of female births. While the biologically normal range is around 1.05 (105 boys for every 100 girls), significant deviations can indicate the presence of gender-based sex selection.

Measures the age dependency ratio, which is the ratio of dependents to the working-age population, expressed as the number of dependents per 100 people of working age. Dependents are defined as individuals younger than 15 or older than 64, while the working-age population comprises those aged 15-64. This ratio indicates the potential pressure on the productive population to support the non-productive, younger and older, segments of society.

Measures the old-age dependency ratio, which is the ratio of the older dependent population (ages 65 and over) to the working-age population (ages 15-64). The data is expressed as the number of older dependents per 100 working-age individuals. This indicator specifically highlights the burden on the productive population to support the elderly, a key metric for assessing the sustainability of social security and healthcare systems in aging societies.

Measures the youth dependency ratio, which is the ratio of the younger dependent population (ages 0-14) to the working-age population (ages 15-64). It is expressed as the number of young dependents per 100 working-age individuals. This indicator reflects the pressure on the working population to support children, which has implications for public spending on education, childcare, and healthcare for the young.

Measures the annual population growth rate, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the exponential rate of growth of the midyear population from one year to the next. This rate reflects the net change in population resulting from births, deaths, and international migration. The population figures are based on the de facto definition, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship.

Measures the number of researchers engaged in research and development (R&D), expressed per million people. Researchers are defined as professionals who create new knowledge, concepts, and theories, and this category includes doctoral students engaged in R&D. The data is presented in full-time equivalents (FTE) and covers basic research, applied research, and experimental development across various scientific fields. This indicator reflects a country's human capital investment in innovation.

Measures the number of technicians involved in research and development (R&D), expressed per million people. Technicians are personnel who perform scientific and technical tasks under the supervision of researchers, applying concepts and operational methods. The data is based on full-time equivalents (FTE) and encompasses R&D activities including basic research, applied research, and experimental development. This indicator represents the level of technical support available for a country's innovation activities.

Represents the total population of a country, comprising all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. The figures are midyear estimates based on the de facto definition of population. Data are derived from national population censuses and demographic models that account for fertility, mortality, and migration rates. This is a fundamental indicator for assessing a country's size and demographic characteristics.

Measures the total female population of a country. This figure represents a midyear estimate based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all female residents regardless of their legal status or citizenship. The data is derived from demographic models that disaggregate the total population by sex and age.

Measures the share of the total population that is female, expressed as a percentage. The calculation is based on midyear estimates using the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. This indicator reflects the gender composition of a country's population.

Measures the total male population of a country. This figure represents a midyear estimate based on the de facto definition of population, which includes all male residents regardless of their legal status or citizenship. The data is derived from demographic models that disaggregate the total population by sex and age.

Measures the share of the total population that is male, expressed as a percentage. The calculation is based on midyear estimates using the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. This indicator reflects the gender composition of a country's population.

Measures the completeness of birth registration for females, expressed as the percentage of female children under the age of five whose births have been officially registered with a civil authority. The data is primarily collected through household surveys. A child's birth is considered registered if the mother or caretaker reports it as such or if a birth certificate is presented to the interviewer.

Measures the completeness of birth registration for males, expressed as the percentage of male children under the age of five whose births have been officially registered with a civil authority. The data is primarily collected through household surveys. A child's birth is considered registered if the mother or caretaker reports it as such or if a birth certificate is presented to the interviewer.

Measures the completeness of birth registration in rural areas, expressed as the percentage of children under the age of five living in these areas whose births have been officially registered. Data is collected via household surveys, and a birth is counted as registered if a birth certificate is seen or if the caretaker confirms registration. This indicator highlights disparities in access to civil registration services between different geographic areas.

Measures the completeness of birth registration in urban areas, expressed as the percentage of children under the age of five living in these areas whose births have been officially registered. Data is collected via household surveys, and a birth is counted as registered if a birth certificate is seen or if the caretaker confirms registration. This indicator helps assess access to civil registration in urban settings.

Measures the overall completeness of birth registration, representing the percentage of all children under the age of five whose births have been officially recorded by a civil authority. Data is sourced from household surveys where registration is confirmed by caretaker report or by sight of a birth certificate. This indicator is a key measure for SDG Target 16.9, which aims to provide legal identity for all.

Measures the completeness of death registration, estimated as the percentage of all deaths in a given year that are registered with cause-of-death information in a country's vital registration system. The calculation divides the total number of registered deaths with a specified cause by the total estimated deaths for that year. This indicator is crucial for understanding mortality patterns and public health priorities.

Measures the total number of people living in areas defined as rural by national statistical offices. The value is calculated as the difference between a country's total population and its urban population. A key limitation is the lack of a standardized international definition for 'rural', as classification criteria vary by country, which affects cross-country comparability.

Measures the annual exponential growth rate of the rural population, expressed as a percentage. This rate is calculated based on the change in the midyear rural population from one year to the next. Since the definition of 'rural' is determined by national statistical offices and is not standardized globally, caution is advised when comparing this growth rate across countries.

Represents the percentage of a country's total population that lives in areas classified as rural. This indicator is calculated by dividing the rural population by the total population. The definition of 'rural' is based on criteria established by national statistical offices, which can vary significantly between countries, impacting the comparability of this metric.

Measures the annual exponential growth rate of the urban population, expressed as a percentage. The calculation is based on the change in the midyear urban population from one year to the next. The definition of 'urban' areas is determined by national statistical offices and is not standardized internationally, which limits the direct comparability of this indicator across countries.

Measures the total number of people living in areas defined as urban by national statistical offices. The data is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects. A significant limitation is that there is no universal standard for defining urban areas, with criteria varying by country based on population size, density, or administrative status.

Represents the percentage of a country's total population living in areas classified as urban. The indicator is calculated by dividing the urban population by the total population. Definitions of 'urban' are based on criteria set by national statistical offices and are not internationally standardized, which requires caution when making cross-country comparisons.

Measures the percentage of married women of reproductive age (15-49) who are fertile and wish to avoid pregnancy but are not using any form of contraception. This indicator reflects the gap between women's reproductive intentions and their contraceptive behavior. The calculation excludes women who are not at risk of unintended pregnancy due to factors like menopause or infertility.

Measures the number of international tourist arrivals in a country. A tourist is defined as a visitor who travels to a country other than their usual residence for a period not exceeding 12 months, for a purpose other than being remunerated from within the country visited. This metric counts the number of arrivals, not unique individuals, so one person making multiple trips is counted each time. Data sources can vary (border statistics, accommodation surveys), affecting cross-country comparability.

Measures the number of international tourism departures from a country. This represents the count of residents traveling outside their country of usual residence for any purpose other than an activity remunerated from within the visited country. The indicator reflects the number of trips, not the number of unique people, meaning a person who travels abroad multiple times in a year is counted for each departure.

Represents the total expenditures by international inbound visitors within a country, measured in current U.S. dollars. This includes payments for goods and services, payments to national carriers for international transport, and any prepayments. The data may also cover spending by same-day visitors. This indicator is a key measure of the economic contribution of tourism.

Measures international tourism receipts as a percentage of a country's total exports of goods and services. Tourism receipts are the expenditures by international inbound visitors, including payments to national carriers for transport. This indicator highlights the relative economic importance of tourism as a source of foreign exchange earnings compared to other export sectors.

Measures the receipts from international visitors for passenger transport services provided by a country's resident carriers, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This includes fares, charges for excess baggage, and on-board expenditures. It is a specific component of total tourism receipts and excludes cruise fares, which are classified under travel items.

Measures the expenditures by a country's residents (outbound visitors) for passenger transport services provided by non-resident carriers, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This includes fares, fees for excess baggage, and on-board purchases. It is a specific component of total tourism expenditures and excludes cruise fares, which are categorized under travel items.

Measures the expenditures by international inbound visitors on goods and services within the reporting economy, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This corresponds to the 'travel' item in the balance of payments and reflects in-country spending by tourists. It excludes payments for international transport, which are recorded separately as 'passenger transport items'.

Measures the expenditures of a country's residents on goods and services while they are traveling abroad as international visitors, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This represents the 'travel' item in the balance of payments for outflows. It specifically excludes payments made for international transport, which are classified under 'passenger transport items'.

Measures the total expenditures of a country's residents while traveling abroad as international visitors, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This is a comprehensive measure that includes both spending in other countries (travel items) and payments to foreign carriers for international transport (passenger transport items). It reflects the total economic outflow associated with outbound tourism.

Measures international tourism expenditures as a percentage of a country's total imports of goods and services. Tourism expenditures include spending by residents traveling abroad plus payments to foreign carriers for transport. This indicator shows the relative scale of tourism-related spending outflows compared to the country's total import bill.

Measures the sum of merchandise exports and imports as a share of Gross Domestic Product (GDP), expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as (Merchandise Exports + Merchandise Imports) / GDP. This indicator is often used to gauge a country's trade openness. It specifically covers trade in goods, excluding services and non-monetary gold.

Represents the change in the physical volume of a country's imports, presented as an index with the base year 2015 equal to 100. It is calculated by dividing the import value index by the corresponding unit value (price) index, thereby removing the effect of price changes. This provides a measure of real import growth.

Measures the percentage of tariff lines for manufactured products that have a 'bound rate.' A bound rate is the maximum tariff level that a country has legally committed to not exceed under World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements. A higher binding coverage signifies greater predictability and stability in a country's trade policy for manufactured goods.

Represents the simple, unweighted average of the 'bound' tariff rates for manufactured products. Bound rates are the maximum, legally enforceable tariff levels committed to at the World Trade Organization (WTO). This calculation only includes tariff lines for which a binding has been set, and each line is given equal weight regardless of its trade value.

Measures the simple, unweighted average of the effectively applied tariff rates for all manufactured products. This is the rate that is actually charged on imports. The calculation gives equal weight to each tariff line, regardless of import volume. Where applied rates are unavailable, the most favored nation (MFN) rate is used instead.

Measures the simple, unweighted average of the most favored nation (MFN) tariff rates for manufactured products. MFN tariffs are the standard rates that a country applies to imports from other WTO members, absent any preferential trade agreements. The calculation gives equal weight to each tariff line, providing an overview of the baseline tariff structure.

Measures the weighted average of the effectively applied tariff rates for manufactured products, using the import value of each product line as the weight. This reflects the average tariff actually paid by importers of manufactured goods, as it gives more importance to products with higher trade volumes. It provides an economically significant measure of trade protection.

Measures the weighted average of the most favored nation (MFN) tariff rates for manufactured products, where the weight for each tariff line is its share of total imports. This indicator reflects the average MFN tariff level while accounting for the economic importance of different imported goods, offering insight into the structure of trade protection.

Measures the percentage of all product tariff lines that are 'bound' under World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements. A bound tariff is a legally committed ceiling on the import duty that a country can levy on a product. This indicator reflects the extent of a country's commitment to tariff predictability across its entire range of goods.

Represents the simple, unweighted average of the 'bound' tariff rates across all product lines for which a country has made a legal commitment at the World Trade Organization (WTO). A bound rate is the maximum enforceable tariff. This metric provides a general measure of a country's legally committed tariff ceilings, treating all product lines equally.

Measures the simple, unweighted average of the effectively applied tariff rates for all products subject to tariffs. This rate is what is actually charged on imports. The calculation treats each tariff line equally, regardless of its import volume. Where applied rates are not available, the most favored nation (MFN) rate is used.

Measures the simple, unweighted average of the most favored nation (MFN) tariff rates applied to all products. MFN tariffs are the standard, non-discriminatory rates that WTO members apply to each other. This indicator provides a broad overview of a country's baseline tariff policy, giving equal weight to every product line.

Measures the weighted average of the effectively applied tariff rates for all products, using each product's share of total imports as the weight. This metric reflects the average tariff level actually encountered by importers, as it gives greater significance to goods with higher trade volumes. It is a key indicator of a country's overall trade restrictiveness.

Measures the average Most Favored Nation (MFN) tariff rate across all products, expressed as a percentage. The methodology uses a weighted mean, where each tariff rate is weighted by its corresponding share of total imports. This approach gives greater significance to products with higher import volumes, reflecting the overall economic impact of tariffs. Data is classified using the Harmonized System (HS), and import weights are calculated from the UN Comtrade database.

Represents the percentage of tariff lines for primary products that are subject to a legally committed maximum tariff rate, known as a 'bound rate,' under World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of bound tariff lines by the total number of tariff lines for primary products. Primary products are defined as commodities in SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 plus division 68 (nonferrous metals), reflecting a country's commitment to tariff predictability in key commodity sectors.

Measures the simple mean of all 'bound' tariff rates for primary products, expressed as a percentage. A bound rate is the maximum Most Favored Nation (MFN) tariff level that a country has committed to in the World Trade Organization (WTO). The calculation is an unweighted average of all committed rates, giving each tariff line equal importance regardless of its import volume. This indicator covers primary products as defined by SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 and division 68 (nonferrous metals).

Indicates the average of the tariff rates that are actually applied to imports of primary products, expressed as a percentage. This is a simple mean, meaning it's an unweighted average across all relevant tariff lines, where each product is given equal weight regardless of trade volume. If an effectively applied rate is unavailable, the Most Favored Nation (MFN) rate is used. Primary products are defined as SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 plus division 68 (nonferrous metals).

Measures the simple mean of Most Favored Nation (MFN) tariff rates for primary products, expressed as a percentage. The MFN rate is the non-discriminatory tariff a country applies to imports from other WTO members. The calculation is an unweighted average of all MFN rates for primary products, meaning each tariff line has equal weight, irrespective of import value. Primary products are defined as SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 and division 68 (nonferrous metals).

Measures the average tariff rate that is actually applied to imports of primary products, expressed as a percentage. The calculation is a weighted mean, where each applied tariff rate is weighted by the import value of the corresponding product. This method gives greater importance to products with higher trade volumes. Primary products are defined as commodities in SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 plus division 68 (nonferrous metals).

Represents the average Most Favored Nation (MFN) tariff rate for primary products, expressed as a percentage. The calculation uses a weighted mean, where each MFN tariff rate is weighted by its corresponding share of total imports. This reflects the economic significance of tariffs on different products. Primary products are defined as commodities classified in SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 and division 68 (nonferrous metals).

Measures the change in the average price of a country's merchandise imports over time. It is presented as an index with the base year 2015 set to 100. An index value above 100 indicates that the average price of imports has risen since 2015, while a value below 100 signifies a decrease. The index is based on unit values (value divided by quantity) derived from trade data, providing a measure of import price inflation.

Measures the value of imported agricultural raw materials as a share of a country's total merchandise imports, expressed as a percentage. This category is defined by Section 2 of the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC) Revision 3, which includes crude materials. Key exclusions from this category are oil-seeds and oleaginous fruits (division 22), crude fertilizers and minerals (division 27), and metalliferous ores and scrap (division 28).

Represents the share of a country's total merchandise imports that is composed of food products, expressed as a percentage. The definition of food is comprehensive, including commodities from SITC Revision 3 sections 0 (food and live animals), 1 (beverages and tobacco), and 4 (animal and vegetable oils and fats), as well as division 22 (oil seeds, oil nuts, and oil kernels). The indicator reflects a country's reliance on imported food.

Measures the value of fuel imports as a percentage of a country's total merchandise imports. This indicator highlights a nation's dependence on foreign energy sources. The 'fuels' category is defined by Section 3 of the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC) Revision 3, which encompasses mineral fuels, lubricants, and related materials.

Measures the share of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) goods in a country's total merchandise imports, expressed as a percentage. ICT goods include computers and peripheral equipment, communication devices, consumer electronics, and electronic components. This indicator reflects a country's integration into the global digital economy and its reliance on foreign technology hardware. Software is generally excluded as it is classified as a service.

Represents the value of imported insurance and financial services as a share of a country's total commercial service imports, expressed as a percentage. This category includes services related to financial intermediation, risk management, liquidity transformation, as well as insurance, reinsurance, and pension services. The indicator helps gauge the extent to which a country relies on foreign providers for its financial and insurance needs.

Measures the value of manufactured goods imports as a percentage of a country's total merchandise imports. This indicator reflects a country's demand for foreign industrial products. 'Manufactures' include commodities from SITC Revision 3 sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods). A key exclusion from this category is non-ferrous metals (division 68).

Represents the share of a country's total merchandise imports composed of ores and metals, expressed as a percentage. This indicator highlights a nation's reliance on foreign raw materials for industrial production. The category includes commodities from SITC Revision 3 divisions 27 (crude fertilizers and minerals), 28 (metalliferous ores and scrap), and 68 (non-ferrous metals).

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from economies in the Arab World, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the value of goods imported from this specific partner group by the reporting country's total merchandise imports. The indicator helps assess the trade relationship and import dependency on this particular economic bloc.

Measures the total value of all merchandise goods imported by a country from the rest of the world. The value is expressed in current U.S. dollars and is typically recorded on a cost, insurance, and freight (c.i.f.) basis, reflecting the landed cost at the point of entry. This indicator provides a comprehensive measure of a country's total spending on foreign goods. It excludes services, non-monetary gold, and goods under merchanting.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from high-income economies, as classified by the World Bank. Expressed as a percentage, it is calculated by dividing the value of imports from this group by the reporting country's total merchandise imports. The indicator provides insight into trade patterns and sourcing dependencies between economies at different income levels.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise imports that comes from low- and middle-income economies located outside of its own geographic region. Expressed as a percentage, this indicator is calculated based on World Bank regional and income classifications. It highlights the extent of a country's trade diversification and its import relationships with developing economies in other parts of the world.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the East Asia & Pacific region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the Europe & Central Asia region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the Latin America & the Caribbean region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the Middle East & North Africa region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the South Asia region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Measures the proportion of a country's total merchandise imports that originates from low- and middle-income economies in the Sub-Saharan Africa region. Expressed as a percentage, the indicator is based on World Bank regional and income classifications and helps to quantify the trade linkages with this specific group of economies.

Represents the share of a country's total merchandise imports that cannot be attributed to a specific partner country or income group, expressed as a percentage. This residual value captures trade with unspecified partners or with economies not included in the standard World Bank income classifications (high, middle, and low). It is calculated by subtracting the sum of imports from all classified economies from total merchandise imports.

Measures the total value of all merchandise goods imported by a country from all trading partners worldwide. Expressed in current U.S. dollars, this value is based on data from the reporting economy as compiled in the IMF's Direction of Trade database. It provides an aggregate figure for a country's imports, typically valued on a cost-insurance-freight (CIF) basis, and serves as a key component of the trade balance.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise imports that comes from other low- and middle-income economies located within its same geographic region. Expressed as a percentage, this indicator highlights the intensity of intra-regional trade among developing economies. The regional and income groupings are based on the World Bank classification system. This metric is not applicable to high-income economies.

Tracks the change in the total value (price multiplied by quantity) of a country's merchandise imports over time. It is presented as an index with the base year 2015 set to 100. A value greater than 100 indicates that the total U.S. dollar value of imports has increased compared to 2015. This index reflects the combined effect of changes in both the price and volume of imported goods.

Measures the share of a country's total commercial service imports that is composed of computer, communications, and other miscellaneous services. Expressed as a percentage, this broad category includes international telecommunications, postal and courier services, construction services, royalties and license fees, as well as various business, professional, technical, personal, and cultural services.

Measures the total monetary value of commercial services provided by non-residents to residents of a country, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This value is not adjusted for inflation. The indicator is a key component of a country's balance of payments and covers all service imports with the specific exclusion of government services that are not classified elsewhere. Data is based on Balance of Payments statistics from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

Measures the share of transport services in a country's total commercial service imports, expressed as a percentage. Transport services encompass the carriage of people and goods, related support and auxiliary services, as well as postal and courier services. This indicator is calculated by dividing the value of transport service imports by the total value of commercial service imports, providing insight into a country's reliance on foreign transportation for international trade and travel.

Represents the share of travel-related expenditures within a country's total commercial service imports, expressed as a percentage. This category includes all goods and services that a country's residents acquire from other economies for their own use during visits abroad. It captures the spending by domestic travelers in foreign countries, reflecting the economic impact of international tourism and business travel on the national balance of payments.

Measures the relative price of a country's exports compared to its imports, presented as an index with the base year 2015 set to 100. It is calculated by dividing the export unit value index by the import unit value index and multiplying by 100. A value greater than 100 signifies that the terms of trade have improved relative to the base year, allowing the country to buy more imports for a given quantity of exports, while a value below 100 indicates a worsening of the terms of trade.

Represents the share of medium- and high-technology products within a country's total manufactured exports, expressed as a percentage. The classification of goods into technology categories is based on the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC). This indicator reflects the technological sophistication and value-added component of a country's industrial export base, often used to gauge its global competitiveness and position in advanced production chains.

Measures the change in the physical quantity of a country's merchandise exports over time, relative to a base year (2015=100). This index is calculated by deflating the export value index with the corresponding export unit value (price) index, thereby isolating changes in volume from changes in price. A value greater than 100 indicates that the volume of exported goods has increased compared to the base year, providing a measure of real export growth.

Tracks the average change in the prices of a country's merchandise exports over time, presented as an index with the base year 2015 equal to 100. It is constructed using unit values derived from customs data, reflecting the average price per unit of exported goods. This index is a key component for calculating the terms of trade and for deflating export values to measure real export volume growth. A value above 100 indicates that export prices have increased since the base year.

Measures the share of agricultural raw materials in a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. This category, defined by the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC Rev. 3), primarily includes inedible crude materials like cotton, rubber, and wood. It specifically excludes fuels, oil-seeds, crude fertilizers and minerals, and metalliferous ores and scrap. The indicator highlights a country's reliance on exporting unprocessed agricultural commodities.

Represents the share of food products in a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. According to the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC Rev. 3), the food category includes food and live animals, beverages and tobacco, animal and vegetable oils and fats, as well as oil seeds, nuts, and kernels. This indicator reflects the importance of the food and agriculture sector in a country's export economy.

Measures the share of fuels in a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. This category is defined by Section 3 of the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC Rev. 3) and includes mineral fuels, lubricants, and related materials such as petroleum, coal, and natural gas. The indicator is a key measure of a country's dependence on energy resources for its export earnings.

Represents the share of information and communication technology (ICT) goods within a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. This category includes products such as computers and peripheral equipment, communication devices, consumer electronics, and electronic components, while generally excluding software. The indicator highlights the role of the technology manufacturing sector in a country's trade profile and its integration into global electronics supply chains.

Measures the share of insurance and financial services in a country's total commercial service exports, expressed as a percentage. This category encompasses services related to financial intermediation, risk management, liquidity transformation, and auxiliary financial activities. It also includes life and non-life insurance, reinsurance, pension services, and standardized guarantees. The indicator reflects the international competitiveness and scale of a country's financial sector.

Measures the share of manufactured goods in a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. According to the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC Rev. 3), this category includes chemicals, basic manufactures, machinery and transport equipment, and miscellaneous manufactured articles. A key exclusion from this group is non-ferrous metals. This indicator is a broad measure of a country's industrialization level and its capacity to export processed goods.

Represents the share of ores and metals in a country's total merchandise exports, expressed as a percentage. This category, defined by the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC Rev. 3), includes crude fertilizers and minerals, metalliferous ores and scrap, and non-ferrous metals. The indicator highlights a country's reliance on exporting mineral and metal resources, reflecting the significance of its mining and metallurgical industries to its trade balance.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports that are destined for economies in the Arab World, expressed as a percentage. This indicator is calculated by dividing the value of goods exported to this specific group of partner countries by the reporting economy's total merchandise exports. It provides insight into the geographic concentration of trade and the importance of the Arab World as an export market for the reporting country.

Represents the total value of all goods provided by a country to the rest of the world, measured in current U.S. dollars. This figure captures transactions where the economic ownership of goods changes from a resident to a non-resident. Exports are valued on a free on board (f.o.b.) basis, and key exclusions include goods under merchanting and non-monetary gold. This indicator is a fundamental measure of a country's international trade performance.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports that are destined for high-income economies, as defined by the World Bank's classification, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated by dividing the value of exports to this group of countries by the reporting economy's total merchandise exports. The indicator helps analyze trade patterns and the extent of a country's integration with the world's wealthiest markets.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports that are sent to low- and middle-income economies located outside its own geographic region, expressed as a percentage. The classification of economies by income and region follows the World Bank's definitions. This indicator provides insight into a country's South-South trade patterns and its ability to access developing markets beyond its immediate neighbors.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the East Asia & Pacific region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the East Asia & Pacific market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the Europe & Central Asia region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the Europe & Central Asia market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the Latin America & the Caribbean region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the Latin America & Caribbean market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the Middle East & North Africa region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the Middle East & North Africa market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the South Asia region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the South Asia market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports destined for low- and middle-income economies in the Sub-Saharan Africa region, expressed as a percentage. Based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications, it is calculated by dividing exports to this specific group by total merchandise exports. The indicator helps to quantify the importance of the Sub-Saharan Africa market for the reporting country's export strategy.

Represents the share of a country's total merchandise exports that are not allocated to a specific partner country or are destined for economies not classified by the World Bank's income groupings. This residual value, expressed as a percentage of total merchandise exports, serves as a balancing item and can include trade with unspecified partners. It helps to account for discrepancies or gaps in the detailed, destination-specific trade data.

Measures the total value of all merchandise goods exported by the reporting economy to the rest of the world, expressed in current U.S. dollars. Sourced from the IMF's Direction of Trade database, this indicator provides a comprehensive, aggregate figure for a country's export performance in a given year, reflecting the nominal value of goods for which economic ownership is transferred to non-residents.

Measures the share of a country's total merchandise exports that are destined for other low- and middle-income economies within its own geographic region, expressed as a percentage. Partner countries are identified based on the World Bank's regional and income classifications. This indicator is a key measure of intra-regional trade intensity and economic integration among neighboring developing economies.

Measures the change in the nominal U.S. dollar value of a country's merchandise exports over time, relative to a base year (2015=100). The index is calculated from the current free on board (f.o.b.) export values. A value greater than 100 indicates that the total monetary value of exports has increased since 2015. This index reflects the combined effect of changes in both the prices and the physical quantities of exported goods.

Represents the share of a broad category of services in a country's total commercial service exports, expressed as a percentage. This composite group includes telecommunications, postal and courier services, computer and data services, construction, royalties and license fees, news-related services, miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services, as well as personal, cultural, and recreational services. It captures a significant portion of modern, tradable business and knowledge-based services.

Measures the total monetary value of commercial services provided by residents of a country to non-residents, expressed in current U.S. dollars. This value is not adjusted for inflation. The indicator is a key component of a country's balance of payments and includes all service exports with the specific exclusion of government services that are not classified elsewhere. It reflects the performance of a country's service sector in the global market.

Measures the total value of a country's high-technology exports, expressed in current U.S. dollars. High-technology products are defined by the OECD as goods with high research and development (R&D) intensity. This classification is based on a "product approach" using SITC Rev.4 codes and includes items from sectors like aerospace, computers, pharmaceuticals, scientific instruments, and advanced machinery. The data, sourced from the UN Comtrade database, reflects gross exports minus re-exports.

Represents the share of high-technology exports as a percentage of a country's total manufactured exports. High-technology products are classified based on their R&D intensity, following the OECD's "product approach." This includes goods from sectors such as aerospace, computers, pharmaceuticals, and electronics. The indicator is calculated by dividing the value of high-technology exports by the total value of manufactured exports, providing insight into the technological sophistication of a country's export profile.

Measures the share of transport services within a country's total commercial service exports, expressed as a percentage. Based on IMF Balance of Payments statistics, this indicator covers services provided by residents to non-residents for the carriage of people and goods. It includes all modes of transport, related supporting and auxiliary services, as well as postal and courier services. The data helps assess the international competitiveness of a country's transportation sector.

Indicates the share of travel services in a country's total commercial service exports, expressed as a percentage. Travel services cover the value of goods and services acquired by non-residents during their visits to the reporting economy. This includes expenditures on accommodation, food, entertainment, and local transport. The data is based on IMF Balance of Payments statistics and serves as a key measure of the economic contribution of international tourism.

Represents a country's score on the 'Voice and Accountability' dimension of the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI). It captures perceptions of the extent to which citizens can participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media. The estimate is presented in units of a standard normal distribution, ranging approximately from -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong). The score is an aggregate of views from numerous enterprise, citizen, and expert surveys.

Indicates the total number of underlying data sources used to calculate a country's 'Voice and Accountability' estimate within the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI). These sources include surveys of households and firms, as well as assessments from commercial business information providers, NGOs, and public sector organizations. This metric provides insight into the breadth of information and robustness of the aggregate governance score, with a higher number of sources generally suggesting a more reliable estimate.

Measures a country's percentile rank on the 'Voice and Accountability' dimension of the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI). This rank, ranging from 0 (lowest) to 100 (highest), indicates the country's position relative to all other countries covered in the assessment. A higher rank signifies stronger perceived performance in areas such as political participation, freedom of expression, and free media. The ranks are adjusted to account for changes in the set of countries covered over time.

Represents the lower bound of the 90% confidence interval for a country's 'Voice and Accountability' score, expressed in terms of its percentile rank (0-100). As part of the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI), this statistical measure reflects the margin of error in the estimate. It indicates the bottom of the statistically likely range for the country's true governance performance, providing a more cautious assessment of its global standing on this dimension.

Represents the upper bound of the 90% confidence interval for a country's 'Voice and Accountability' score, expressed as a percentile rank (0-100). This metric, from the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI), accounts for the statistical margin of error. It signifies the top of the statistically likely range for the country's true governance performance, offering an optimistic boundary for its rank compared to other nations.

Measures the standard error associated with the 'Voice and Accountability' estimate from the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI). This statistical value quantifies the precision of the governance score, where a larger standard error indicates less precision. The standard error is influenced by the number of available data sources for a country and the degree of agreement among them. It is used to calculate the confidence intervals around the main estimate, highlighting the inherent uncertainty in measuring governance.

Measures the total number of deaths, both military and civilian, that are a direct consequence of combat between warring parties in a conflict. Data is sourced from the Uppsala Conflict Data Program (UCDP). This includes fatalities from traditional battlefield engagements, guerrilla warfare, and bombardments of military or civilian areas. To be included, a conflict must involve at least one state and result in a minimum of 25 battle-related deaths within a calendar year.

Represents the number of new cases or incidents of internal displacement within a country's borders caused by conflict and violence during a given year. An internally displaced person (IDP) is someone forced to flee their home who has not crossed an international border. Data is provided by the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC). This indicator counts displacement events rather than individuals, as one person may be displaced multiple times.

Measures the number of new cases or incidents of internal displacement within a country's borders caused by natural or human-made disasters during a given year. Sourced from the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC), this indicator applies to individuals forced from their homes who remain within their own country. It counts the number of displacement events, not the total number of people, as individuals can be displaced on multiple occasions.

Measures the rate of unlawful, intentional killings of females, expressed per 100,000 female population. Sourced from the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), the data is compiled from criminal justice and public health systems. The definition includes homicides resulting from domestic disputes, interpersonal violence, and other criminal activities. A key exclusion is deaths occurring in armed conflict.

Measures the rate of unlawful, intentional killings of males, expressed per 100,000 male population. Data from the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) is based on national criminal justice and public health records. This indicator covers homicides from interpersonal violence, gang-related activities, and other criminal acts. It explicitly excludes deaths that are a direct result of armed conflict.

Represents the rate of intentional homicides, defined as unlawful deaths purposefully inflicted by another person, expressed per 100,000 people. Data is compiled by the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) from national criminal justice and public health sources. This indicator includes killings from domestic disputes, gang violence, and other interpersonal conflicts but excludes deaths related to armed conflict and unintentional killings.
